src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhjNO7RwCdlB6y_dfklFN6uJAEWuV2K-dPXjXjoNVPT_x9MsARxpLNLj5ISTj666uo_9avS2 生成式人工智能的最新进展释放了在多个不同领域（包括文本、视觉和音频）创建新内容的可能性。这些模型通常依赖于这样一个事实：原始数据首先转换为压缩格式作为令牌序列。对于音频，神经音频编解码器（例如，<a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2021/08/soundstream-end-to-end-neural-audio.html">;SoundStream</a >; 或 <a href="https://github.com/facebookresearch/encodec">;EnCodec</a>;）可以有效地将波形压缩为紧凑的表示形式，可以将其反转以重建原始音频信号的近似值。这种表示由一系列离散音频标记组成，捕获声音的本地属性（例如，<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoneme">;音素</a>;）及其时间结构（例如，<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosody_(linguistics)">;韵律</a>;）。通过将音频表示为一系列离散标记，可以使用 <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2017/08/transformer-novel-neural-network.html">;Transformer</a 来生成音频基于>;的序列到序列模型——这开启了语音延续的快速进展（例如，使用<a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/10/audiolm-language-modeling-approach-to .html">;AudioLM</a>;），文本转语音（例如，使用 <a href="https://google-research.github.io/seanet/speartts/examples/">;SPEAR-TTS</ a>;），以及一般音频和音乐生成（例如，<a href="https://felixkreuk.github.io/audiogen/">;AudioGen</a>; 和 <a href="https://google-research .github.io/seanet/musiclm/examples/">;MusicLM</a>;）。许多生成音频模型，包括 AudioLM，都依赖于自动回归解码，它会一一生成令牌。虽然这种方法实现了高音质，但推理（即计算输出）可能很慢，尤其是在解码长序列时。 </p>;<a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; 要解决此问题，请在“<a href="https://google-research.github.io/seanet/soundstorm/examples/”中>;SoundStorm：高效并行音频生成</a>;”，我们提出了一种高效、高质量音频生成的新方法。 SoundStorm 通过依赖两个新颖元素来解决生成长音频令牌序列的问题：1) 适应 SoundStream 神经编解码器生成的音频令牌特定性质的架构，以及 2) 受 <a href=" 启发的解码方案https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.04200">;MaskGIT</a>;，这是最近提出的一种图像生成方法，专门针对音频令牌进行操作。与AudioLM的自回归解码方法相比，SoundStorm能够并行生成token，从而将长序列的推理时间减少100倍，并产生相同质量的音频，并且在语音和声学条件下具有更高的一致性。此外，我们还展示了 SoundStorm 以及 <a href="https://google-research.github.io/seanet/speartts/examples/">;SPEAR-TTS</a>; 的文本到语义建模阶段，可以合成高质量、自然的对话，允许控制语音内容（通过文字记录）、说话者声音（通过简短的语音提示）和说话者轮流（通过文字记录注释），如下例所示：</p>; <br>; 设计</h2>; <p>; 在我们之前关于 AudioLM 的工作中，我们展示了音频生成可以分解为两个部分步骤：1) 语义建模，从先前的语义标记或条件信号（例如，SPEAR-TTS 中的转录本，或 MusicLM 中的文本提示）生成语义标记，2) 声学建模，生成声学标记来自语义标记。通过 SoundStorm，我们专门解决了第二个声学建模步骤，用更快的并行解码取代了较慢的自回归解码。 </p>; <p>; SoundStorm 依赖于基于双向注意力的 <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.08100">;Conformer</a>;，这是一种将 Transformer 与卷积相结合来捕获数据的模型架构标记序列的局部和全局结构。具体来说，该模型经过训练，可以在给定 AudioLM 生成的语义标记序列作为输入的情况下预测 SoundStream 生成的音频标记。执行此操作时，重要的是要考虑到这样一个事实：在每个时间步 <em>;t</em>;，SoundStream 使用最多 <em>;Q</em>; 个标记来使用称为的方法来表示音频<em>;残差矢量量化</em>; (RVQ)，如下右图所示。关键的直觉是，随着每一步生成的令牌数量从 1 到 <em>;Q</em>;，重建音频的质量逐渐提高。 </p>; <p>; 在推理时，给定语义标记作为输入调节信号，SoundStorm 首先屏蔽所有音频标记，并从 RVQ 级别的粗标记开始，通过多次迭代填充屏蔽标记 <em>; q = 1</em>; 并使用更精细的标记逐级进行，直到达到 <em>;q = Q</em>; 级别。 </p>; <p>; SoundStorm 有两个关键方面可以实现快速生成：1) 在 RVQ 级别内的单次迭代期间并行预测令牌，2) 模型架构的设计方式使得复杂性仅受级别数 <em>;Q</em>; 的轻微影响。为了支持这种推理方案，在训练期间，使用精心设计的掩蔽方案来模拟推理中使用的迭代过程。 </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; 我们承认模型生成的音频样本可能会受到训练数据中存在的不公平偏见的影响，例如在所代表的口音方面在我们生成的样本中，我们证明了我们可以通过提示可靠且负责任地控制说话者的特征，以避免不公平的偏见。根据我们负责任的<a href="http://ai.google/principles">;AI 原则</a>;，对任何训练数据及其局限性进行彻底分析是未来工作的一个领域。 </p>; <p>; 反过来，模仿声音的能力可能有许多恶意应用，包括绕过生物识别和使用该模型进行模仿。因此，制定防止潜在滥用的保护措施至关重要：为此，我们已经验证了 SoundStorm 生成的音频仍然可以被专用分类器检测到，该专用分类器使用与我们原始 AudioLM 论文中描述的相同分类器。因此，作为一个更大系统的组件，我们相信 SoundStorm 不太可能给我们之前关于 AudioLM 和 SPEAR-TTS 的论文中讨论的风险带来额外的风险。与此同时，放宽 AudioLM 的内存和计算要求将使音频生成领域的研究更容易被更广泛的社区所接受。未来，我们计划探索其他方法来检测合成语音，例如借助音频水印，以便该技术的任何潜在产品使用都严格遵循我们负责任的人工智能原则。 </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;结论</h2>; <p>; 我们引入了SoundStorm，一个可以高效合成高质量的模型来自离散调节令牌的音频。与 <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/10/audiolm-language-modeling-approach-to.html">;AudioLM</a>; 的声音发生器相比，SoundStorm 是两个数量级在生成长音频样本时，幅度更快并实现更高的时间一致性。通过将类似于 <a href="https://google-research.github.io/seanet/spearts/examples/">;SPEAR-TTS</a>; 的文本到语义标记模型与 SoundStorm 相结合，我们可以扩展文本到语音合成更长的上​​下文，并通过多个发言者轮流生成自然对话，控制发言者的声音和生成的内容。 SoundStorm 不仅限于生成语音。例如，MusicLM 使用 SoundStorm 高效地合成较长的输出（<a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/05/google-research-at-io-2023.html">;如 I/O 上所示</a>;）。 </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;致谢</h2>; <p>; <em>;此处描述的工作由 Zalán Borsos、Matt 创作谢里菲、达米安·文森特、尤金·哈里托诺夫、尼尔·泽吉杜尔和马可·塔利亚萨基。我们感谢 Google 同事对这项工作的所有讨论和反馈。</em>; </p>; name='more'>;</a>; <p>; 在这篇博文中，我们讨论 <a href="https://sites.research.google/euphonia/about/">;项目所做的工作Euphonia</a>; 是 <a href="https://ai.google/responsibility/social-good/">;AI for Social Good</a>; 内的一个团队，旨在<a href="https:/ /ai.googleblog.com/2019/08/project-euphonias-personalized-speech.html">;改进针对言语障碍人士的自动语音识别</a>; (ASR)。对于具有典型语音的人来说，ASR 模型的单词错误率 (WER) 可以低于 10%。但对于言语模式紊乱的人，例如口吃，<a href="https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/dysarthria/symptoms-causes/syc-20371994">;构音障碍</a>;和<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apraxia">;失用症</a>;，根据病因和严重程度，WER 可能达到 50% 甚至 90%。为了帮助解决这个问题，我们与 1,000 多名参与者合作，<a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/accessibility/project-euphonia-1000-hours-speech-recordings/">;收集了 1,000 多个数小时的无序语音样本</a>;，并使用这些数据显示 ASR <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2021/09/personalized-asr-models-from-large-and.html" >;个性化</a>;是弥补言语障碍用户性能差距的可行途径。我们已经证明，使用 <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.04612">;3-4 分钟的培训演讲</a>;即可成功实现个性化https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.13511">;层冻结技术</a>;。 </p>; <p>; 这项工作促成了 <a href="https://sites.research.google/relate/">;Project Relate</a>; 的开发，任何具有非典型言语的人都可以从中受益个性化语音模型。 Project Relate 与 <a href="https://research.google/research-areas/speech-processing/">;Google 语音团队</a>;合作构建，帮助那些难以被他人理解的人，技术来训练自己的模型。人们可以使用这些个性化模型来更有效地沟通并获得更多的独立性。为了使 ASR 更易于访问和使用，我们介绍了如何微调 Google 的 <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/03/universal-speech-model-usm-state-of-art.html ">;通用语音模型</a>; (USM) 可更好地理解开箱即用的无序语音，无需个性化，可与数字助理技术、听写应用程序和对话中使用。 </p>; <br />; <h2>;应对挑战</h2>; <p>; 通过与 Project Relate 用户密切合作，我们发现个性化模型非常有用，但对于许多用户来说，记录数十或数百个示例可能具有挑战性。此外，个性化模型在自由对话中并不总是表现良好。 </p>; <p>; 为了应对这些挑战，Euphonia 的研究工作一直集中在<em>;与说话人无关</em>;的 ASR (SI-ASR) 上，以使模型能够更好地为言语障碍者提供开箱即用的效果，以便无需额外培训。 </p>; <br />; <h2>;SI-ASR 提示语音数据集</h2>; <p>; 构建稳健的 SI-ASR 模型的第一步是创建代表性数据集分割。我们通过将 <a href="https://www.isca-speech.org/archive/pdfs/interspeech_2021/macdonald21_interspeech.pdf">;Euphonia 语料库</a>; 分为训练、验证和测试部分来创建提示语音数据集，同时确保每个分割涵盖一系列言语障碍严重程度和潜在病因，并且多个分割中没有出现说话者或短语。训练部分由 1,000 多个言语紊乱的说话者的超过 950k 条语音组成。该测试集包含来自 350 多个说话者的约 5,700 条话语。言语病理学家手动审查测试集中的所有话语，以确保转录准确性和音频质量。 </p>; <br />; <h2>;真实对话测试集</h2>; <p>; 无提示或对话式语音在几个方面与有提示的语音不同。在谈话中，人们说话速度更快，发音更少。他们重复单词、修复说错的单词，并使用针对他们自己和社区的特定和个人的更广泛的词汇。为了改进此用例的模型，我们创建了真实对话测试集来基准性能。 </p>; <p>; 真实对话测试集是在值得信赖的测试人员的帮助下创建的，他们在对话期间录制了自己的讲话。音频经过审查，所有个人身份信息 (PII) 都被删除，然后由言语病理学家转录该数据。真实对话测试集包含 29 位说话者的 1,500 多个话语。 </p>; <br />; <h2>;使 USM 适应无序语音</h2>; <p>; 然后，我们在 Euphonia 提示语音集的训练分割上调整 USM，以提高其在无序语音上的性能。我们的调整不是对整个模型进行微调，而是基于<a href="http://proceedings.mlr.press/v97/houlsby19a/houlsby19a.pdf">;剩余适配器</a>;，这是一种参数高效的调整添加可调瓶颈层作为变压器层之间的残差的方法。仅调整这些层，而模型权重的其余部分保持不变。我们<a href="https://aclanthology.org/2021.emnlp-main.541/">;之前已经表明</a>;这种方法非常适合使 ASR 模型适应无序语音。残余适配器仅添加到编码器层，瓶颈维度设置为 64。 </p>; <br />; <h2>;结果</h2>; <p>; 为了评估调整后的 USM，我们将其与旧的 ASR 进行了比较使用上述两个测试集的模型。对于每个测试，我们将改编后的 USM 与最适合该任务的 USM 之前的模型进行比较：（1）对于简短的提示语音，我们与针对简短形式 ASR 优化的 Google 生产 ASR 模型进行比较； (2) 对于较长的真实对话语音，我们与<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.03271">;针对长格式 ASR 进行训练的模型</a>;进行比较。 USM 相对于 USM 之前的模型的改进可以通过 USM 的相对大小增加、120M 到 2B 参数以及 <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/03/universal-speech- model-usm-state-of-art.html">;USM 博客文章</a>;。 </p>; <table 想象一下，您看到两个相同的物体，然后要求您闭上眼睛。当你睁开眼睛时，你会看到相同位置的两个相同的物体。如何确定它们是否已被来回交换？直觉和量子力学定律一致：如果物体确实相同，则无法判断。 </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; 虽然这听起来像是常识，但它只适用于我们熟悉的三维世界。研究人员预测，对于一种称为<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anyon">;任意子</a>;的特殊类型粒子，它只能在<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anyon">;任意粒子</a>;中移动。 ="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plane_(mathematics)">;二维</a>; (2D) 平面，量子力学允许一些完全不同的东西。任意子彼此之间无法区分，并且一些非阿贝尔任意子具有一种特殊属性，该属性会导致交换下的共享量子态存在可观察到的差异，从而可以判断它们何时被交换，尽管它们彼此完全无法区分。虽然研究人员已经成功地检测到它们的亲戚阿贝尔任意子，其交换下的变化更加微妙且不可能直接检测到，但由于控制和检测方面的挑战，实现“非阿贝尔交换行为”被证明更加困难。 </p>; <p>; 在“<a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-05954-4">;超导处理器中图顶点的非阿贝尔编织</a>; ”，发表在<em>;<a href="https://www.nature.com/">;自然</a>;</em>;上，我们首次报告了对这种非阿贝尔交换行为的观察。非阿贝尔任意子可以为量子计算开辟一条新途径，其中量子运算是通过相互交换粒子来实现的，就像字符串相互交换以创建辫子一样。在我们的<a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2019/10/quantum-supremacy-using-programmable.html">;超导量子处理器</a>;上实现这种新的交换行为可能是实现这一目标的另一种途径所谓的<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/9707021">;拓扑量子计算</a>;，它受益于对环境噪声的鲁棒性。 </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;交换统计和非阿贝尔任意子</h2>; <p>; 为了理解这个奇怪的现象非阿贝尔行为可能会发生，考虑与两根弦的编织进行类比会很有帮助。取两根相同的绳子，将它们平行并排放置。交换它们的末端以形成双螺旋形状。字符串是相同的，但由于交换两端时它们会相互缠绕，因此交换两端时非常清晰。 </p>; <p>; 非阿贝尔任意子的交换可以用类似的方式可视化，其中弦是通过将粒子的位置扩展到时间维度以形成“世界线”而形成的。想象一下绘制两个粒子的位置与时间的关系。如果粒子保持原状，绘图将只是两条平行线，代表它们的恒定位置。但如果我们交换粒子的位置，世界线就会相互缠绕。第二次交换它们，你就打了一个<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knot_theory">;结</a>;。 </p>; <p>; 虽然有点难以想象，但四个维度（三个空间加一个时间维度）的结总是可以轻松解开。它们很微不足道——就像鞋带一样，只需拉动一端，它就会散开。但是，当粒子被限制在两个空间维度时，结就处于三个总维度中，并且正如我们从日常 3D 生活中知道的那样，并不总是能轻易解开。非阿贝尔任意子世界线的编织可以用作量子计算操作来改变粒子的状态。 </p>; <p>; 非阿贝尔任意子的一个关键方面是“简并性”：几个分离的任意子的完整状态并不完全由局部信息指定，允许相同的任意子配置表示几个量子态的叠加。非阿贝尔任意子相互缠绕可以改变编码状态。 </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;如何制作非阿贝尔任意子</h2>; <p>; 那么我们如何实现非阿贝尔任意子呢？ - 使用 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sycamore_processor">;Google 量子处理器</a>;之一进行阿贝尔编织？我们从熟悉的表面代码开始，我们最近使用它实现了<a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/02/suppressing-quantum-errors-by-scaling.html">;量子领域的里程碑纠错</a>;，其中量子位排列在棋盘图案的顶点上。棋盘的每个颜色方块代表可以由方块四个角上的量子位进行的两种可能的联合测量之一。这些所谓的“稳定器测量”可以返回 + 或 – 1 的值。后者被称为小板违规，可以通过应用单量子位 <a 来创建和对角移动——就像国际象棋中的象一样。 href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_logic_gate">;X 门和 Z 门</a>;。最近，我们证明了这些类似主教的<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.01180">;牌匾违规是阿贝尔任意子</a>;。与非阿贝尔任意子相比，阿贝尔任意子的状态只有在交换时才会发生微妙的变化——变化如此微妙以至于无法直接检测到。虽然阿贝尔任意子很有趣，但它们在拓扑量子计算方面的前景并不像非阿贝尔任意子那样。 </p>; <p>; 为了产生非阿贝尔任意子，我们需要控制简并性（即<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wave_function">;波函数的数量</a >; 导致所有<a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003491623000714">;稳定器</a>;测量值为+1）。由于稳定器测量返回两个可能的值，因此每个稳定器将系统的简并性减半，并且在足够多的稳定器的情况下，只有一个波函数满足标准。因此，增加简并性的一个简单方法是将两个稳定剂合并在一起。在此过程中，我们删除了稳定器网格中的一条边，从而产生只有三个边相交的两个点。这些点被称为“<a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003491623000714">;3 度顶点</a>;”(D3Vs)，预计是非阿贝尔任意子。 </p>; <p>; 为了编织 D3V，我们必须移动它们，这意味着我们必须将稳定器拉伸并挤压成新的形状。我们通过在任意子及其邻居之间实现两个量子位门来实现这一点（如下所示的中图和右图）。 </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fusion_of_anyons">;融合规则</a>;”——当非阿贝尔任意子相互碰撞时会发生什么？ </li>;<li>;交换统计数据——当它们相互缠绕时会发生什么？ </li>;<li>;拓扑量子计算基元 - 我们可以用非阿贝尔任意子编码量子位并使用编织来执行<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_entanglement">;两个量子位纠缠操作</a>;？ </li>; </ol>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;非阿贝尔任意子的融合规则</h2>; <我们通过研究一对 D3V 如何与上面介绍的类似主教斑块违规相互作用来研究融合​​规则。特别是，我们创建了一对，并通过应用单量子位门将其中一个置于 D3V 周围。 </p>; <p>; 虽然国际象棋中主教的规则规定棋盘违规行为永远不能相遇，但棋盘格中的错位允许他们打破这一规则，与对手相遇并与之消灭。牌匾违规行为现已消失！但是，让非阿贝尔任意子重新相互接触，任意子就会突然变成缺失的斑块破坏。尽管这种行为看起来很奇怪，但它恰恰是我们期望这些实体遵守的融合规则的体现。这建立了 D3V 确实是非阿贝尔任意子的信心。 </p>; <table align="center" />; </div>; <h2>;非阿贝尔交换统计观察</h2>; <p>; 建立融合规则后，我们希望看到非阿贝尔任意子的真实证据：非阿贝尔交换统计数据。我们创建两对非阿贝尔任意子，然后通过将每对任意子中的一个相互缠绕来将它们编成辫子（如下所示）。当我们将这两对重新融合在一起时，就会出现两对斑块违规。将任意子相互编织的简单行为改变了我们系统的可观测值。换句话说，如果你在交换非阿贝尔任意子时闭上眼睛，那么当你睁开眼睛时，你仍然能够知道它们已经被交换了。这是非阿贝尔统计的标志。 scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Machine Learning">;</category>;<title type="text">;Speed is all you need: On-device acceleration of large diffusion models via GPU-aware optimizations</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by Juhyun Lee and Raman Sarokin, Software Engineers , Core Systems & Experiences</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjm8J7pV44tX5D9h_So9djOQ6574uRfNDoRjQDgg8kN78DFf7H3N8y7AIEnHfGJCqbYqxN9ZJVs9PaQ2B0qQ7SoXgjGEzEVfcuPQZCKQqMjqR7kDZ7rk_vjR_RFRiw-OoW7k-KjF5ecEkEVNiX2_27bePakLG6Ac805m8q6YhQPaA3IEWaWpmFbrLsWKg/s700/SpeedHero.png" style="display: none;" />; <p>; The proliferation of large <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2021/07/high-fidelity-image-generation-using.html">;diffusion models</a>; for <a href="https://ai.google/discover/foundation-models/">;image generation</a>; has led to a significant increase in model size and inference workloads. On-device ML inference in mobile environments requires meticulous performance optimization and consideration of trade-offs due to resource constraints. Running inference of large diffusion models (LDMs) on-device, driven by the need for cost efficiency and user privacy, presents even greater challenges due to the substantial memory requirements and computational demands of these models. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; We address this challenge in our work titled “<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11267">;Speed Is All You Need: On-Device Acceleration of Large Diffusion Models via GPU-Aware Optimizations</a>;” (to be presented at the <a href="https://cvpr2023.thecvf.com/Conferences/2023">;CVPR 2023</a>; workshop for <a href="https://sites.google.com/corp/view/ecv23">;Efficient Deep Learning for Computer Vision</a>;) focusing on the optimized execution of a foundational LDM model on a mobile GPU. In this blog post, we summarize the core techniques we employed to successfully execute large diffusion models like <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.10752">;Stable Diffusion</a>; at full resolution (512x512 pixels) and 20 iterations on modern smartphones with high-performing inference speed of the original model without distillation of under 12 seconds. As discussed in <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/08/high-definition-segmentation-in-google.html">;our previous blog post</a>;, GPU-accelerated ML inference is often limited by memory performance, and execution of LDMs is no exception. Therefore, the central theme of our optimization is efficient memory input/output (I/O) even if it means choosing memory-efficient algorithms over those that prioritize arithmetic logic unit efficiency. Ultimately, our primary objective is to reduce the overall latency of the ML inference. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgSvrG_xr7MWV45RJH9aZr8I9a1wlYHLjVx9hJrCnLoC9xa0Y0h1N_LX0df8pa7yVKLfj6S8SH_RDx-p7obVNBu5A18uabECxdt4_14ixwjQXKE2y4jqajgAD4Okt6p48ju20n1zttBdM2D2woOdEX6gxgUzvLKQ6vie6GJBf_sSQt9UwhEMU0piYQPJQ/s512/image4.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="512" data-original-width="512" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgSvrG_xr7MWV45RJH9aZr8I9a1wlYHLjVx9hJrCnLoC9xa0Y0h1N_LX0df8pa7yVKLfj6S8SH_RDx-p7obVNBu5A18uabECxdt4_14ixwjQXKE2y4jqajgAD4Okt6p48ju20n1zttBdM2D2woOdEX6gxgUzvLKQ6vie6GJBf_sSQt9UwhEMU0piYQPJQ/s16000/image4.jpg" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;A sample output of an LDM on Mobile GPU with the prompt text: “a photo realistic and high resolution image of a cute puppy with surrounding flowers”.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Enhanced attention module for memory efficiency</h2>; <p>; An ML inference engine typically provides a variety of optimized ML operations. Despite this, achieving optimal performance can still be challenging as there is a certain amount of overhead for executing individual neural net operators on a GPU. To mitigate this overhead, ML inference engines incorporate extensive operator fusion rules that consolidate multiple operators into a single operator, thereby reducing the number of iterations across tensor elements while maximizing compute per iteration. For instance, <a href="https://www.tensorflow.org/lite">;TensorFlow Lite</a>; utilizes operator fusion to combine computationally expensive operations, like convolutions, with subsequent activation functions, like <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rectifier_(neural_networks)">;rectified linear units</a>;, into one. </p>; <p>; A clear opportunity for optimization is the heavily used attention block adopted in the <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/2304.11267.pdf">;denoiser model</a>; in the LDM. The attention blocks allow the model to focus on specific parts of the input by assigning higher weights to important regions. There are multiple ways one can optimize the attention modules, and we selectively employ one of the two optimizations explained below depending on which optimization performs better. </p>; <p>; The first optimization, which we call <em>;partially fused <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Softmax_function">;softmax</a>;</em>;, removes the need for extensive memory writes and reads between the softmax and the matrix multiplication in the attention module. Let the attention block be just a simple matrix multiplication of the form <b>;<em>;Y </em>;</b>;= softmax(<b>;<em>;X</em>;</b>;) * <b>;<em>;W</em>;</b>; where <b>;<em>;X</em>;</b>; and <b>;<em>;W</em>;</b>; are 2D matrices of shape <em>;a</em>;×<em>;b</em>; and <em>;b</em>;×<em>;c</em>;, respectively (shown below in the top half). </p>; <p>; For numerical stability, <b>;<em>;T = </em>;</b>;softmax(<b>;<em>;X</em>;</b>;) is typically calculated in three passes: </p>; <ol>; <li>;Determine the maximum value in the list, <em>;ie</em>;.,<em>; </em>;for each row in matrix <b>;<em>;X</em>;</b>; </li>;<li>;Sum up the differences of the exponential of each list item and the maximum value (from pass 1) </li>;<li>;Divide the exponential of the items minus the maximum value by the sum from pass 2 </li>; </ol>; <p>; Carrying out these passes naïvely would result in a huge memory write for the temporary intermediate tensor <strong>;<em>;T</em>;</strong>; holding the output of the entire softmax function. We bypass this large memory write if we only store the results of passes 1 and 2, labeled <b>;<em>;m</em>;</b>; and <b>;<em>;s</em>;</b>;, respectively, which are small vectors, with <em>;a</em>; elements each, compared to <strong>;<em>;T </em>;</strong>;which has <em>;a·b </em>;elements. With this technique, we are able to reduce tens or even hundreds of megabytes of memory consumption by multiple orders of magnitude (shown below in the bottom half). </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjmMWkT7U6yQ7m4JegrYpJRUt6gO6dMBb16fvNQIdiaX6gRRWP7uHykb6PBNoI0LyuqFTdJc1sJgWIq1bO4j1l4x_LokTvrPVDCEnbLBAgXqd8QBAGHxCLVaWlEMYWhmW2CC4rzuKwqC06MLQ-8MVAfEea4SwSngu4-YxcMYHzEyrTF3X7lZhLHkUjmcg/s568/image1.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="457" data-original-width="568" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjmMWkT7U6yQ7m4JegrYpJRUt6gO6dMBb16fvNQIdiaX6gRRWP7uHykb6PBNoI0LyuqFTdJc1sJgWIq1bO4j1l4x_LokTvrPVDCEnbLBAgXqd8QBAGHxCLVaWlEMYWhmW2CC4rzuKwqC06MLQ-8MVAfEea4SwSngu4-YxcMYHzEyrTF3X7lZhLHkUjmcg/s16000/image1.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Attention modules. <b>;Top</b>;: A naïve attention block, composed of a SOFTMAX (with all three passes) and a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_multiplication">;MATMUL</a>;, requires a large memory write for the big intermediate tensor <em>;T</em>;. <b>;Bottom</b>;: Our memory-efficient attention block with partially fused softmax in MATMUL only needs to store two small intermediate tensors for <em>;m</em>; and s.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; The other optimization involves employing <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.14135">;FlashAttention</a>;, which is an I/O-aware, exact attention algorithm. This algorithm reduces the number of GPU high-bandwidth memory accesses, making it a good fit for our memory bandwidth–limited use case. However, we found this technique to only work for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Static_random-access_memory">;SRAM</a>; with certain sizes and to require a large number of registers. Therefore, we only leverage this technique for attention matrices with a certain size on a select set of GPUs. </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Winograd fast convolution for 3×3 convolution layers</h2>; <p>; The backbone of common LDMs heavily relies on 3×3 convolution layers (convolutions with filter size 3×3), comprising over 90% of the layers in the decoder. Despite increased memory consumption and numerical errors, we found that <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1509.09308">;Winograd fast convolution</a>; to be effective at speeding up the convolutions. Distinct from the <em>;filter size</em>; 3x3 used in convolutions, <em>;tile size</em>; refers to the size of a sub region of the input tensor that is processed at a time. Increasing the tile size enhances the efficiency of the convolution in terms of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arithmetic_logic_unit">;arithmetic logic unit</a>; (ALU) usage. However, this improvement comes at the expense of increased memory consumption. Our tests indicate that a tile size of 4×4 achieves the optimal trade-off between computational efficiency and memory utilization. </p>; <br>; <table align="center" style="text-align: center">; <tbody>;<tr>; <td>;</td>; <td>;</td>; <td colspan="2">;<b>;    Memory usage    </b>; </td>; </tr>; <tr>; <td>;<b>;    Tile size    </b>; </td>; <td>;<b>;    <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FLOPS">;FLOPS</a>; savings    </b>; </td>; <td>;<b>;    Intermediate tensors    </b>; </td>; <td>;<b>;    Weights    </b>; </td>; </tr>; <tr>; <td>;2×2 </td>; <td>;2.25× </td>; <td>;4.00× </td>; <td>;1.77× </td>; </tr>; <tr>; <td>;<b>;4×4</b>; </td>; <td>;<b>;4.00×</b>; </td>; <td>;<b>;2.25×</b>; </td>; <td>;<b>;4.00×</b>; </td>; </tr>; <tr>; <td>;6×6 </td>; <td>;5.06× </td>; <td>;1.80× </td>; <td>;7.12× </td>; </tr>; <tr>; <td>;8×8 </td>; <td>;5.76× </td>; <td>;1.56× </td>; <td>;11.1× </td>; </tr>; </tbody>;</table>; <br>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Impact of Winograd with varying tile sizes for 3×3 convolutions.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Specialized operator fusion for memory efficiency</h2>; <p>; We discovered that performantly inferring LDMs on a mobile GPU requires significantly larger fusion windows for commonly employed layers and units in LDMs than current off-the-shelf on-device GPU-accelerated ML inference engines provide. Consequently, we developed specialized implementations that could execute a larger range of neural operators than typical fusion rules would permit. Specifically, we focused on two specializations: the <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.08415">;Gaussian Error Linear Unit</a>; (GELU) and the <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.08494">;group normalization</a>; layer. </p>; <p>; An approximation of GELU with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperbolic_functions">;hyperbolic tangent</a>; function requires writing to and reading from seven auxiliary intermediate tensors (shown below as light orange rounded rectangles in the figure below), reading from the input tensor <em>;x</em>; three times, and writing to the output tensor <em>;y</em>; once across eight GPU programs implementing the labeled operation each (light blue rectangles). A custom GELU implementation that performs the eight operations in a single shader (shown below in the bottom) can bypass all the memory I/O for the intermediate tensors. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEilG64yPIiXZN5SpvnvPua9d9TFGiFcTLZhZX00gmnOMpzOoEHX5agNOyorx6uCABcYc0oRMvsWUkuIz7vK1_yzhpGb77BJ2ZLKMj640ILhSKruDK0utP5wqD5TSjF2gfB3QWLwJOkseGrwzAhjmxtriTklmsZnTuFQDx3jeF_T7wux1gR0QIpSLYtkjg/s958/image2.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="210" data-original-width="958" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEilG64yPIiXZN5SpvnvPua9d9TFGiFcTLZhZX00gmnOMpzOoEHX5agNOyorx6uCABcYc0oRMvsWUkuIz7vK1_yzhpGb77BJ2ZLKMj640ILhSKruDK0utP5wqD5TSjF2gfB3QWLwJOkseGrwzAhjmxtriTklmsZnTuFQDx3jeF_T7wux1gR0QIpSLYtkjg/s16000/image2.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;GELU implementations. <strong>;Top</strong>;: A naïve implementation with built-in operations would require 8 memory writes and 10 reads. <strong>;Bottom</strong>;: Our custom GELU only requires 1 memory read (for <em>;x</em>;) and 1 write (for <em>;y</em>;).</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Results</h2>; <p>; After applying all of these optimizations, we conducted tests of Stable Diffusion 1.5 (image resolution 512x512, 20 iterations) on high-end mobile devices. Running Stable Diffusion with our GPU-accelerated ML inference model uses 2,093MB for the weights and 84MB for the intermediate tensors. With latest high-end smartphones, Stable Diffusion can be run in under 12 seconds. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgN0IRuIecTfbuq2ztTqfcahyGfGkYum_4_wvf6rfwRKkvlYZOpq7Cw2l4T5QL08ElzKIn97dpXqARuUfRp08ugvGG4SFSS6ZfzXlF3usn9J4tUEa5iXrmRZQVxY0CQjiP9VCNhxRB333HK84HdwYd58iN6JwqePj-TGqvM0WV8A4N4D7yDUZ0Adxm1Ig/s522/image3.gif" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="522" data-original-width="270" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgN0IRuIecTfbuq2ztTqfcahyGfGkYum_4_wvf6rfwRKkvlYZOpq7Cw2l4T5QL08ElzKIn97dpXqARuUfRp08ugvGG4SFSS6ZfzXlF3usn9J4tUEa5iXrmRZQVxY0CQjiP9VCNhxRB333HK84HdwYd58iN6JwqePj-TGqvM0WV8A4N4D7yDUZ0Adxm1Ig/s16000/image3.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Stable Diffusion runs on modern smartphones in under 12 seconds. Note that running the decoder after each iteration for displaying the intermediate output in this animated GIF results in a ~2× slowdown.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Conclusion</h2>; <p>; Performing on-device ML inference of large models has proven to be a substantial challenge, encompassing limitations in model file size, extensive runtime memory requirements, and protracted inference latency. By recognizing memory bandwidth usage as the primary bottleneck, we directed our efforts towards optimizing memory bandwidth utilization and striking a delicate balance between ALU efficiency and memory efficiency. As a result, we achieved state-of-the-art inference latency for large diffusion models. You can learn more about this work in <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11267">;the paper</a>;. </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Acknowledgments</h2>; <p>; <em>;We'd like to thank Yu-Hui Chen, Jiuqiang Tang, Frank Barchard, Yang Zhao, Joe Zou, Khanh LeViet, Chuo-Ling Chang, Andrei Kulik, Lu Wang, and Matthias Grundmann.</em>; </p>; </content>;<link scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Augmented Reality">;</category>;<category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Computational Photography">;</category>;<category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Google Maps">;</category>;<title type="text">;Reconstructing indoor spaces with NeRF</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Marcos Seefelder, Software Engineer, and Daniel Duckworth, Research Software Engineer, Google Research</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhxGrEnhxjRJV-5Ws2doej6GjSpHuwLJBxjBbQnqzlVhuBAyBAKRmz0LuAYLSGHqtMPEfyZf9HIxVdNGhOsvMnlZKC6gnTq0oEFw0-YjU-yoHXXUhV1ZCWNxJVZUW4_rnT6ktLhHh4TjLfS9B2A4Txv5kKF3FZcxBU4q8ktQoaNPERvfLV1S9zHzCaLQQ/s320/Immersive%20View%20hero.gif" style="display: none;" />; <p>; When choosing a venue, we often find ourselves with questions like the following: Does this restaurant have the right vibe for a date? Is there good outdoor seating? Are there enough screens to watch the game? While photos and videos may partially answer questions like these, they are no substitute for feeling like you're there, even when visiting in person isn't an option. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; Immersive experiences that are interactive, photorealistic, and multi-dimensional stand to bridge this gap and recreate the feel and vibe of a space, empowering users to naturally and intuitively find the information they need. To help with this, Google Maps launched <a href="https://blog.google/products/maps/google-maps-updates-immersive-view-trip-planning">;Immersive View</a>;, which uses advances in machine learning (ML) and computer vision to fuse billions of <a href="https://www.google.com/streetview/">;Street View</a>; and aerial images to create a rich, digital model of the world. Beyond that, it layers helpful information on top, like the weather, traffic, and how busy a place is. Immersive View provides indoor views of restaurants, cafes, and other venues to give users a virtual up-close look that can help them confidently decide where to go. </p>; <p>; Today we describe the work put into delivering these indoor views in Immersive View. We build on <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.08934">;neural radiance fields</a>; (NeRF), a state-of-the-art approach for fusing photos to produce a realistic, multi-dimensional reconstruction within a neural network. We describe our pipeline for creation of NeRFs, which includes custom photo capture of the space using DSLR cameras, image processing and scene reproduction. We take advantage of Alphabet's <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2008.02268">;recent</a>; <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.12077">;advances</a>; <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.05263">;in the field</a>; to design a method matching or outperforming the prior state-of-the-art in visual fidelity. These models are then embedded as interactive 360° videos following curated flight paths, enabling them to be available on smartphones. </p>; <br />; <video autoplay="" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" style="margin-left: 5%; margin-right: 5%;" width="90%">; <source src="https://storage.googleapis.com/jax3d-public/projects/dinnerf-blog/introduction_resized.mp4" type="video/mp4">;</source>; </video>; <br />; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;The reconstruction of The Seafood Bar in Amsterdam in Immersive View.</td>;</tr>; </tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;From photos to NeRFs</h2>; <p>; At the core of our work is <a href="https://www.matthewtancik.com/nerf">;NeRF</a>;, a recently-developed method for 3D reconstruction and novel view synthesis. Given a collection of photos describing a scene, NeRF distills these photos into a <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.11426">;neural field</a>;, which can then be used to render photos from viewpoints not present in the original collection. </p>; <p>; While NeRF largely solves the challenge of reconstruction, a user-facing product based on real-world data brings a wide variety of challenges to the table. For example, reconstruction quality and user experience should remain consistent across venues, from dimly-lit bars to sidewalk cafes to hotel restaurants. At the same time, privacy should be respected and any potentially personally identifiable information should be removed. Importantly, scenes should be captured consistently and efficiently, reliably resulting in high-quality reconstructions while minimizing the effort needed to capture the necessary photographs. Finally, the same natural experience should be available to all mobile users, regardless of the device on hand. </p>; <video autoplay="" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" width="100%">; <source src="https://storage.googleapis.com/jax3d-public/projects/dinnerf-blog/overview_resized.mp4" type="video/mp4">;</source>; </video>; <br />; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;The Immersive View indoor reconstruction pipeline.</td>;</tr>; </tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Capture & preprocessing</h2>; <p>; The first step to producing a high-quality NeRF is the careful capture of a scene: a dense collection of photos from which 3D geometry and color can be derived. To obtain the best possible reconstruction quality, every surface should be observed from multiple different directions. The more information a model has about an object's surface, the better it will be in discovering the object's shape and the way it interacts with lights. </p>; <p>; In addition, NeRF models place further assumptions on the camera and the scene itself. For example, most of the camera's properties, such as white balance and aperture, are assumed to be fixed throughout the capture. Likewise, the scene itself is assumed to be frozen in time: lighting changes and movement should be avoided. This must be balanced with practical concerns, including the time needed for the capture, available lighting, equipment weight, and privacy. In partnership with professional photographers, we developed a strategy for quickly and reliably capturing venue photos using DSLR cameras within only an hour timeframe. This approach has been used for all of our NeRF reconstructions to date. </p>; <p>; Once the capture is uploaded to our system, processing begins. As photos may inadvertently contain sensitive information, we automatically scan and blur personally identifiable content. We then apply a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structure_from_motion">;structure-from-motion</a>; pipeline to solve for each photo's <a href="https://www.mathworks.com/help/vision/ug/camera-calibration.html">;camera parameters</a>;: its position and orientation relative to other photos, along with lens properties like <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focal_length">;focal length</a>;. These parameters associate each pixel with a point and a direction in 3D space and constitute a key signal in the NeRF reconstruction process. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;NeRF reconstruction</h2>; <p>; Unlike many ML models, a new NeRF model is trained from scratch on each captured location. To obtain the best possible reconstruction quality within a target compute budget, we incorporate features from a variety of published works on NeRF developed at Alphabet. Some of these include: </p>; <ul>; <li>;We build on <a href="https://jonbarron.info/mipnerf360/">;mip-NeRF 360</a>;, one of the best-performing NeRF models to date. While more computationally intensive than Nvidia's widely-used <a href="https://nvlabs.github.io/instant-ngp/">;Instant NGP</a>;, we find the mip-NeRF 360 consistently produces fewer artifacts and higher reconstruction quality. </li>;<li>;We incorporate the low-dimensional generative latent optimization (GLO) vectors introduced in <a href="https://nerf-w.github.io/">;NeRF in the Wild</a>; as an auxiliary input to the model's radiance network. These are learned real-valued latent vectors that embed appearance information for each image. By assigning each image in its own latent vector, the model can capture phenomena such as lighting changes without resorting to cloudy geometry, a common artifact in casual NeRF captures. </li>;<li>;We also incorporate exposure conditioning as introduced in <a href="https://waymo.com/research/block-nerf/">;Block-NeRF</a>;. Unlike GLO vectors, which are uninterpretable model parameters, exposure is directly derived from a photo's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exif">;metadata</a>; and fed as an additional input to the model's radiance network. This offers two major benefits: it opens up the possibility of varying <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Film_speed#Digital_camera_ISO_speed_and_exposure_index">;ISO</a>; and provides a method for controlling an image's brightness at inference time. We find both properties invaluable for capturing and reconstructing dimly-lit venues. </li>; </ul>; <p>; We train each NeRF model on TPU or GPU accelerators, which provide different trade-off points. As with all Google products, we continue to search for new ways to improve, from reducing compute requirements to improving reconstruction quality. </p>; <br />; <video autoplay="" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" style="margin-left: 5%; margin-right: 5%;" width="90%">; <source src="https://storage.googleapis.com/jax3d-public/projects/dinnerf-blog/side_by_side_resized.mp4" type="video/mp4">;</source>; </video>; <br />; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;A side-by-side comparison of our method and a mip-NeRF 360 baseline.</td>;</tr>; </tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;A scalable user experience</h2>; <p>; Once a NeRF is trained, we have the ability to produce new photos of a scene from any viewpoint and camera lens we choose. Our goal is to deliver a meaningful and helpful user experience: not only the reconstructions themselves, but guided, interactive tours that give users the freedom to naturally explore spaces from the comfort of their smartphones. </p>; <p>; To this end, we designed a controllable 360° video player that emulates flying through an indoor space along a predefined path, allowing the user to freely look around and travel forward or backwards. As the first Google product exploring this new technology, 360° videos were chosen as the format to deliver the generated content for a few reasons. </p>; <p>; On the technical side, <a href="https://nvlabs.github.io/instant-ngp/">;real-time inference</a>; and <a href="https://phog.github.io/snerg/">;baked representations</a>; are still resource intensive on a per-client basis (either on device or cloud computed), and relying on them would limit the number of users able to access this experience. By using videos, we are able to scale the storage and delivery of videos to all users by taking advantage of the same video management and serving infrastructure used by YouTube. On the operations side, videos give us clearer editorial control over the exploration experience and are easier to inspect for quality in large volumes. </p>; <p>; While we had considered capturing the space with a 360° camera directly, using a NeRF to reconstruct and render the space has several advantages. A virtual camera can fly anywhere in space, including over obstacles and through windows, and can use any desired camera lens. The camera path can also be edited post-hoc for smoothness and speed, unlike a live recording. A NeRF capture also does not require the use of specialized camera hardware. </p>; <p>; Our 360° videos are rendered by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ray_casting">;ray casting</a>; through each pixel of a virtual, spherical camera and compositing the visible elements of the scene. Each video follows a smooth path defined by a sequence of keyframe photos taken by the photographer during capture. The position of the camera for each picture is computed during structure-from-motion, and the sequence of pictures is smoothly interpolated into a flight path. </p>; <p>; To keep speed consistent across different venues, we calibrate the distances for each by capturing pairs of images, each of which is 3 meters apart. By knowing measurements in the space, we scale the generated model, and render all videos at a natural velocity. </p>; <p>; The final experience is surfaced to the user within <a href="https://blog.google/products/maps/three-maps-updates-io-2022/">;Immersive View</a>;: the user can seamlessly fly into restaurants and other indoor venues and discover the space by flying through the photorealistic 360° videos. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Open research questions</h2>; <p>; We believe that this feature is the first step of many in a journey towards universally accessible, AI-powered, immersive experiences. From a NeRF research perspective, more questions remain open. Some of these include: </p>; <ol>; <li>;Enhancing reconstructions with scene segmentation, adding semantic information to the scenes that could make scenes, for example, searchable and easier to navigate. </li>;<li>;Adapting NeRF to outdoor photo collections, in addition to indoor. In doing so, we'd unlock similar experiences to every corner of the world and change how users could experience the outdoor world. </li>;<li>;Enabling real-time, interactive 3D exploration through neural-rendering on-device. </li>; </ol>; <br />; <video autoplay="" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" style="margin-left: 5%; margin-right: 5%;" width="90%">; <source src="https://storage.googleapis.com/jax3d-public/projects/dinnerf-blog/outdoors_resized.mp4" type="video/mp4">;</source>; </video>; <br />; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Reconstruction of an outdoor scene with a NeRF model trained on Street View panoramas.</td>;</tr>; </tbody>;</table>; <br />; <p>; As we continue to grow, we look forward to engaging with and contributing to the community to build the next generation of immersive experiences. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Acknowledgments</h2>; <p>; <em>;This work is a collaboration across multiple teams at Google. Contributors to the project include Jon Barron, Julius Beres, Daniel Duckworth, Roman Dudko, Magdalena Filak, Mike Harm, Peter Hedman, Claudio Martella, Ben Mildenhall, Cardin Moffett, Etienne Pot, Konstantinos Rematas, Yves Sallat, Marcos Seefelder, Lilyana Sirakovat, Sven Tresp and Peter Zhizhin.</em>; </p>; <p>; <em>;Also, we'd like to extend our thanks to Luke Barrington, Daniel Filip, Tom Funkhouser, Charles Goran, Pramod Gupta, Santi López, Mario Lučić, Isalo Montacute and Dan Thomasset for valuable feedback and suggestions.</em>; </p>;</content>;<link scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Research">;</category>;<title type="text">;Enabling delightful user experiences via predictive models of human attention</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by Junfeng He, Senior Research Scientist, and Kai Kohlhoff, Staff Research Scientist, Google Research</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjerKPFbdl3UNBtSQUQXn94PZtgAw7zM4KC4KRdMJxwP_iQlOUkkg6FYURau3sBRJUkeNXMoiHKy-WRc_d0Ypx4Hh4x8KGUHPkeqCXM7BR7MoX6MVOWTHylNnAcQg4ogEMk7vZJDropM08gc9t1Y2HG-GwolJuWEdhFT19yaJV9gpqbr3_ZBl-geZCfcw/s1400/HumanAttention.png" style="display: none;" />; <p>; People have the remarkable ability to take in a tremendous amount of information (estimated to be ~10<sup>;10</sup>; bits/s entering the retina) and selectively attend to a few task-relevant and interesting regions for further processing (eg, memory, comprehension, action). Modeling human attention (the result of which is often called a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saliency_map">;saliency</a>; model) has therefore been of interest across the fields of neuroscience, psychology, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human%E2%80%93computer_interaction">;human-computer interaction</a>; (HCI) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision">;computer vision</a>;. The ability to predict which regions are likely to attract attention has numerous important applications in areas like graphics, photography, image compression and processing, and the measurement of visual quality. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; We've <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2021/05/accelerating-eye-movement-research-for.html">;previously discussed</a>; the possibility of accelerating eye movement research using machine learning and smartphone-based gaze estimation, which earlier required specialized hardware costing up to $30,000 per unit. Related research includes “<a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/accessibility/look-to-speak/">;Look to Speak</a>;”, which helps users with accessibility needs (eg, people with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS">;ALS</a>;) to communicate with their eyes, and the recently published “<a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/04/differentially-private-heatmaps.html">;Differentially private heatmaps</a>;” technique to compute heatmaps, like those for attention, while protecting users' privacy. </p>; <p>; In this blog, we present two papers (one from <a href="https://cvpr2022.thecvf.com/">;CVPR 2022</a>;, and one just accepted to <a href="https://cvpr2023.thecvf.com/">;CVPR 2023</a>;) that highlight our recent research in the area of human attention modeling: “<a href="https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content/CVPR2022/papers/Aberman_Deep_Saliency_Prior_for_Reducing_Visual_Distraction_CVPR_2022_paper.pdf">;Deep Saliency Prior for Reducing Visual Distraction</a>;” and “<a href="https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content/CVPR2023/papers/Chen_Learning_From_Unique_Perspectives_User-Aware_Saliency_Modeling_CVPR_2023_paper.pdf">;Learning from Unique Perspectives: User-aware Saliency Modeling</a>;”, together with recent research on saliency driven progressive loading for image compression (<a href="https://opensource.googleblog.com/2021/09/using-saliency-in-progressive-jpeg-xl-images.html">;1</a>;, <a href="https://opensource.googleblog.com/2022/12/open-sourcing-attention-center-model.html">;2</a>;). We showcase how predictive models of human attention can enable delightful user experiences such as image editing to minimize visual clutter, distraction or artifacts, image compression for faster loading of webpages or apps, and guiding ML models towards more intuitive human-like interpretation and model performance. We focus on image editing and image compression, and discuss recent advances in modeling in the context of these applications. </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Attention-guided image editing</h2>; <p>; Human attention models usually take an image as input (eg, a natural image or a screenshot of a webpage), and <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1109/TPAMI.2019.2935715">;predict a heatmap as output</a>;. The predicted heatmap on the image is <a href="https://www.computer.org/csdl/journal/tp/2019/03/08315047/17D45Vw15wU">;evaluated against ground-truth attention data</a>;, which are typically collected by an eye tracker or <a href="https://bubbleview.namwkim.org/">;approximated via mouse hovering/clicking</a>;. Previous models leveraged handcrafted features for visual clues, like color/brightness contrast, edges, and shape, while more recent approaches automatically learn discriminative features based on deep neural networks, from <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1805.01047">;convolutional</a>; and <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/1610.01708.pdf">;recurrent neural networks</a>; to more recent <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925231222004714">;vision transformer networks</a>;. </p>; <p>; In “<a href="https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content/CVPR2022/papers/Aberman_Deep_Saliency_Prior_for_Reducing_Visual_Distraction_CVPR_2022_paper.pdf">;Deep Saliency Prior for Reducing Visual Distraction</a>;” (more information on this <a href="https://deep-saliency-prior.github.io/">;project site</a>;), we leverage deep saliency models for dramatic yet visually realistic edits, which can significantly change an observer's attention to different image regions. For example, removing distracting objects in the background can reduce clutter in photos, leading to increased user satisfaction. Similarly, in video conferencing, reducing clutter in the background may increase focus on the main speaker (<a href="https://deep-saliency-prior.github.io/supplementary/index.html">;example demo here</a>;). </p>; <p>; To explore what types of editing effects can be achieved and how these affect viewers' attention, we developed an optimization framework for guiding visual attention in images using a differentiable, predictive saliency model. Our method employs a state-of-the-art deep saliency model. Given an input image and a binary mask representing the distractor regions, pixels within the mask will be edited under the guidance of the predictive saliency model such that the saliency within the masked region is reduced. To make sure the edited image is natural and realistic, we carefully choose four image editing operators: two standard image editing operations, namely recolorization and image warping (shift); and two learned operators (we do not define the editing operation explicitly), namely a multi-layer convolution filter, and a generative model (<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.04958">;GAN</a>;). </p>; <p>; With those operators, our framework can produce a variety of powerful effects, with examples in the figure below, including recoloring, inpainting, camouflage, object editing or insertion, and facial attribute editing. Importantly, all these effects are driven solely by the single, pre-trained saliency model, without any additional supervision or training. Note that our goal is not to compete with dedicated methods for producing each effect, but rather to demonstrate how multiple editing operations can be guided by the knowledge embedded within deep saliency models. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjr1wM-E9N5w73kCxoZKqPxw_J3tWwTU8CjnrOc5vjHo6ILfwHwBzvoRslIHHr105yiyuaAGAb4iwlABhC7P2SufIfcliXyTopTkNGeNAEmMbhtytLGbEwuwdfJrnFr-pWZ_4ARVgAByAe8yL0yYT868hL3eG46uyQvb7rmhD8hqpLimXvbgsS153zRBA/s1999/image2.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="1999" data-original-width="1300" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjr1wM-E9N5w73kCxoZKqPxw_J3tWwTU8CjnrOc5vjHo6ILfwHwBzvoRslIHHr105yiyuaAGAb4iwlABhC7P2SufIfcliXyTopTkNGeNAEmMbhtytLGbEwuwdfJrnFr-pWZ_4ARVgAByAe8yL0yYT868hL3eG46uyQvb7rmhD8hqpLimXvbgsS153zRBA/s16000/image2.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Examples of reducing visual distractions, guided by the saliency model with several operators. The distractor region is marked on top of the saliency map (red border) in each example.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Enriching experiences with user-aware saliency modeling</h2>; <p>; Prior research assumes a single saliency model for the whole population. However, human attention varies between individuals — while the detection of salient clues is fairly consistent, their order, interpretation, and gaze distributions can differ substantially. This offers opportunities to create personalized user experiences for individuals or groups. In “<a href="https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content/CVPR2023/papers/Chen_Learning_From_Unique_Perspectives_User-Aware_Saliency_Modeling_CVPR_2023_paper.pdf">;Learning from Unique Perspectives: User-aware Saliency Modeling</a>;”, we introduce a user-aware saliency model, the first that can predict attention for one user, a group of users, and the general population, with a single model. </p>; <p>; As shown in the figure below, core to the model is the combination of each participant's visual preferences with a per-user attention map and adaptive user masks. This requires per-user attention annotations to be available in the training data, eg, the <a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-020-18360-5">;OSIE mobile gaze dataset for natural images; FiWI</a>; and <a href="http://vision.cs.stonybrook.edu/~soura/websaliency.html">;WebSaliency</a>; datasets for web pages. Instead of predicting a single saliency map representing attention of all users, this model predicts per-user attention maps to encode individuals' attention patterns. Further, the model adopts a user mask (a binary vector with the size equal to the number of participants) to indicate the presence of participants in the current sample, which makes it possible to select a group of participants and combine their preferences into a single heatmap. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh0C16Z2WCjGYbAUdNXg-1Mv4VB_hJSuGVtNnCkfVcVbLxAyOVnuRhJSxbq3G3M-048QOke56RI3hCKho1q3HQKEiYgnwnKQtVnCIUQ1VSJgk-Uhhr3czhCAh3hpcuRPHJ06UCLLDb4n4vkYuJUtILGceRluacg8fIE0eGrD0BqXMWOuVUocUQ7vW6TWg/s1218/image1.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="724" data-original-width="1218" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh0C16Z2WCjGYbAUdNXg-1Mv4VB_hJSuGVtNnCkfVcVbLxAyOVnuRhJSxbq3G3M-048QOke56RI3hCKho1q3HQKEiYgnwnKQtVnCIUQ1VSJgk-Uhhr3czhCAh3hpcuRPHJ06UCLLDb4n4vkYuJUtILGceRluacg8fIE0eGrD0BqXMWOuVUocUQ7vW6TWg/s16000/image1.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;An overview of the user aware saliency model framework. The example image is from <a href="https://www-users.cse.umn.edu/~qzhao/predicting.html">;OSIE</a>; image set.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; During inference, the user mask allows making predictions for any combination of participants. In the following figure, the first two rows are attention predictions for two different groups of participants (with three people in each group) on an image. A <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/1805.01047.pdf">;conventional attention prediction model</a>; will predict identical attention heatmaps. Our model can distinguish the two groups (eg, the second group pays less attention to the face and more attention to the food than the first). Similarly, the last two rows are predictions on a webpage for two distinctive participants, with our model showing different preferences (eg, the second participant pays more attention to the left region than the first). </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEiKRnwjwVWTPvF57HFSZBKCK6sKmL9P30bt0K1zB_z_FeLYBP1sZsI8ZpuK1xxOEpCLQX4p9vdv9VkY855PtAIfs1vYISgJb5nSx4A0gSojHmmehxyaI-UeM9TkreSVAg-r50m7PPBzujbeUuZdU5_mBXEH905kSLikhKudLYQI2DVu_J9RhbIV4jQ1kw/s961/image3.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="533" data-original-width="961" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEiKRnwjwVWTPvF57HFSZBKCK6sKmL9P30bt0K1zB_z_FeLYBP1sZsI8ZpuK1xxOEpCLQX4p9vdv9VkY855PtAIfs1vYISgJb5nSx4A0gSojHmmehxyaI-UeM9TkreSVAg-r50m7PPBzujbeUuZdU5_mBXEH905kSLikhKudLYQI2DVu_J9RhbIV4jQ1kw/s16000/image3.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Predicted attention vs. ground truth (GT). EML-Net: predictions from a state-of-the-art model, which will have the same predictions for the two participants/groups. Ours: predictions from our proposed user aware saliency model, which can predict the unique preference of each participant/group correctly. The first image is from <a href="https://www-users.cse.umn.edu/~qzhao/predicting.html">;OSIE</a>; image set, and the second is from <a href="https://www-users.cse.umn.edu/~qzhao/webpage_saliency.html">;FiWI</a>;.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Progressive image decoding centered on salient features</h2>; <p>; Besides image editing, human attention models can also improve users' browsing experience. One of the most frustrating and annoying user experiences while browsing is waiting for web pages with images to load, especially in conditions with low network connectivity. One way to improve the user experience in such cases is with progressive decoding of images, which decodes and displays increasingly higher-resolution image sections as data are downloaded, until the full-resolution image is ready. Progressive decoding usually proceeds in a sequential order (eg, left to right, top to bottom). With a predictive attention model (<a href="https://github.com/google/attention-center">;1</a>;, <a href="https://opensource.googleblog.com/2021/09/using-saliency-in-progressive-jpeg-xl-images.html">;2</a>;), we can instead decode images based on saliency, making it possible to send the data necessary to display details of the most salient regions first. For example, in a portrait, bytes for the face can be prioritized over those for the out-of-focus background. Consequently, users perceive better image quality earlier and experience significantly reduced wait times. More details can be found in our open source blog posts (<a href="https://opensource.googleblog.com/2021/09/using-saliency-in-progressive-jpeg-xl-images.html">;post 1</a>;, <a href="https://opensource.googleblog.com/2022/12/open-sourcing-attention-center-model.html">;post 2</a>;). Thus, predictive attention models can help with image compression and faster loading of web pages with images, improve rendering for large images and streaming/VR applications. </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Conclusion</h2>; <p>; We've shown how predictive models of human attention can enable delightful user experiences via applications such as image editing that can reduce clutter, distractions or artifacts in images or photos for users, and progressive image decoding that can greatly reduce the perceived waiting time for users while images are fully rendered. Our user-aware saliency model can further personalize the above applications for individual users or groups, enabling richer and more unique experiences. </p>; <p>; Another interesting direction for predictive attention models is whether they can help improve robustness of computer vision models in tasks such as object classification or detection. For example, in “<a href="https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content/CVPR2023/papers/Yao_Teacher-Generated_Spatial-Attention_Labels_Boost_Robustness_and_Accuracy_of_Contrastive_Models_CVPR_2023_paper.pdf">;Teacher-generated spatial-attention labels boost robustness and accuracy of contrastive models</a>;”, we show that a predictive human attention model can guide <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2002.05709">;contrastive learning</a>; models to achieve better representation and improve the accuracy/robustness of classification tasks (on the <a href="https://www.image-net.org/">;ImageNet</a>; and <a href="https://paperswithcode.com/dataset/imagenet-c">;ImageNet-C</a>; datasets). Further research in this direction could enable applications such as using radiologist's attention on medical images to improve health screening or diagnosis, or using human attention in complex driving scenarios to guide autonomous driving systems. </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>; <em>;This work involved collaborative efforts from a multidisciplinary team of software engineers, researchers, and cross-functional contributors. We'd like to thank all the co-authors of the papers/research, including Kfir Aberman, Gamaleldin F. Elsayed, Moritz Firsching, Shi Chen, Nachiappan Valliappan, Yushi Yao, Chang Ye, Yossi Gandelsman, Inbar Mosseri, David E. Jacobes, Yael Pritch, Shaolei Shen, and Xinyu Ye. We also want to thank team members Oscar Ramirez, Venky Ramachandran and Tim Fujita for their help. Finally, we thank Vidhya Navalpakkam for her technical leadership in initiating and overseeing this body of work.</em>; </p>; </content>;<link
