class="byline-author">;Posted by Vincent Cohen-Addad and Alessandro Epasto, Research Scientists, Google Research, Graph Mining team</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjG6jKdvoUMqPI-WRS9KnK6Clj8W-uXfR_Pd3BfLIeSQGMb7sJtp1dTNlITKnF5CTtw4c-JtRIi9r_ySKXmKLeIGBTeLozFnQWQhp6aiXMHVctZjqQfcl2LGDywb3SktCtPwQV9OgAJZ9PyMsAOxeUxxjdRzTf3CIApROfx6hSFBv7NItHKjB8LbFgiTQ/s900/COVID.jpg" style="display: none;" />; <p>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_analysis">;Clustering</a>; is a central problem in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unsupervised_learning">;unsupervised</a>; machine learning (ML) with many applications across domains in both industry and academic research more broadly. At its core, clustering consists of the following problem: given a set of data elements, the goal is to partition the data elements into groups such that similar objects are in the same group, while dissimilar objects are in different groups. This problem has been studied in math, computer science, operations research and statistics for more than 60 years in its myriad variants. Two common forms of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_analysis">;clustering</a>; are metric clustering, in which the elements are points in a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metric_space">;metric space</a>;, like in the <em>;<a href="https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/1056489">;k-means</a>;</em>; problem, and graph clustering, where the elements are nodes of a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_(discrete_mathematics)">;graph</a>; whose edges represent similarity among them. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhaLHvb0dg44mUKzExJZDrM_OgIHx80OnDaguHi6ZyysbfP-iwBEFndK6UfO_y3hvbZKWwJREJTltz6qDr0k5PNqsy-k0WSu4f863w2aKqencPuE7ZKNdqOgckRITkuDDwwEEcvL588GQKjS8Td8Bgz4lQYYgLw7VVMd46DdduACj6iJzbhwmVG4CDfrQ/s596/image1.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="596" data-original-width="592" height="320" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhaLHvb0dg44mUKzExJZDrM_OgIHx80OnDaguHi6ZyysbfP-iwBEFndK6UfO_y3hvbZKWwJREJTltz6qDr0k5PNqsy-k0WSu4f863w2aKqencPuE7ZKNdqOgckRITkuDDwwEEcvL588GQKjS8Td8Bgz4lQYYgLw7VVMd46DdduACj6iJzbhwmVG4CDfrQ/s320/image1.png" width="318" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;In the <em>;<a href="https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/1056489">;k-means</a>;</em>; clustering problem, we are given a set of points in a metric space with the objective to identify <em>;k</em>; representative points, called centers (here depicted as triangles), so as to minimize the sum of the squared distances from each point to its closest center. <a href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Kmeans_toomany.PNG">;Source</a>;, rights: CC-BY-SA-4.0</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; Despite the extensive literature on algorithm design for clustering, few practical works have focused on rigorously protecting the user's privacy during clustering. When clustering is applied to personal data (eg, the queries a user has made), it is necessary to consider the privacy implications of using a clustering solution in a real system and how much information the output solution reveals about the input data. </p>; <p>; To ensure privacy in a rigorous sense, one solution is to develop <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_privacy">;differentially private</a>; (DP) clustering algorithms. These algorithms ensure that the output of the clustering does not reveal private information about a specific data element (eg, whether a user has made a given query) or sensitive data about the input graph (eg, a relationship in a social network). Given the importance of privacy protections in unsupervised machine learning, in recent years Google has invested in research on <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2008.08007">;theory</a>; and <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2021/10/practical-differentially-private.html?hl=el&m=1">;practice</a>; of differentially private <a href="https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper_files/paper/2022/hash/43f55776896a2e33239c2954519f605e-Abstract-Conference.html">;metric</a>; or <a href="https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper_files/paper/2022/hash/da645920dcd3bd35b0dae329894bad80-Abstract-Conference.html">;graph</a>; clustering, and differential privacy in a variety of contexts, eg, <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/04/differentially-private-heatmaps.html">;heatmaps</a>; or <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/12/differential-privacy-accounting-by.html">;tools</a>; to design DP algorithms. </p>; <p>; Today we are excited to announce two important updates: 1) a <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00037">;new differentially-private algorithm</a>; for hierarchical graph clustering, which we'll be presenting at <a href="https://icml.cc/Conferences/2023">;ICML 2023</a>;, and 2) the <a href="https://github.com/google-research/google-research/tree/master/hst_clustering">;open-source release</a>; of the code of a scalable differentially-private <em>;k</em>;-means algorithm. This code brings differentially private <em>;k</em>;-means clustering to large scale datasets using distributed computing. Here, we will also discuss our work on clustering technology for a recent launch in the health domain for informing public health authorities. </p>; <br />; <h2>;Differentially private hierarchical clustering</h2>; <p>; Hierarchical clustering is a popular clustering approach that consists of recursively partitioning a dataset into clusters at an increasingly finer granularity. A well known example of hierarchical clustering is the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phylogenetic_tree">;phylogenetic tree</a>; in biology in which all life on Earth is partitioned into finer and finer groups (eg, kingdom, phylum, class, order, etc.). A hierarchical clustering algorithm receives as input a graph representing the similarity of entities and learns such recursive partitions in an unsupervised way. Yet at the time of our research no algorithm was known to compute hierarchical clustering of a graph with edge privacy, ie, preserving the privacy of the vertex interactions. </p>; <p>; In “<a href="https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2302.00037">;Differentially-Private Hierarchical Clustering with Provable Approximation Guarantees</a>;”, we consider how well the problem can be approximated in a DP context and establish firm upper and lower bounds on the privacy guarantee. We design an approximation algorithm (the first of its kind) with a polynomial running time that achieves both an additive error that scales with the number of nodes <em>;n</em>; (of order <em>;n<sup>;2.5</sup>;</em>;) and a multiplicative approximation of O(log<sup>;½</sup>; n), with the multiplicative error identical to the non-private setting. We further provide a new lower bound on the additive error (of order <em>;n<sup>;2</sup>;</em>;) for any private algorithm (irrespective of its running time) and provide an exponential-time algorithm that matches this lower bound. Moreover, our paper includes a beyond-worst-case analysis focusing on the <a href="https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper/2017/hash/e8bf0f27d70d480d3ab793bb7619aaa5-Abstract.html">;hierarchical stochastic block model</a>;, a standard random graph model that exhibits a natural hierarchical clustering structure, and introduces a private algorithm that returns a solution with an additive cost over the optimum that is negligible for larger and larger graphs, again matching the non-private state-of-the-art approaches. We believe this work expands the understanding of privacy preserving algorithms on graph data and will enable new applications in such settings. </p>; <br />; <h2>;Large-scale differentially private clustering</h2>; <p>; We now switch gears and discuss our work for metric space clustering. Most prior work in DP metric clustering has focused on improving the approximation guarantees of the algorithms on the <em>;k</em>;-means objective, leaving scalability questions out of the picture. Indeed, it is not clear how efficient non-private algorithms such as <em>;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-means%2B%2B">;k-means++</a>;</em>; or <em>;<a href="https://theory.stanford.edu/~sergei/papers/vldb12-kmpar.pdf">;k-means//</a>;</em>; can be made differentially private without sacrificing drastically either on the approximation guarantees or the scalability. On the other hand, both scalability and privacy are of primary importance at Google. For this reason, we recently published <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3534678.3539409">;multiple</a>; <a href="https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper_files/paper/2022/hash/43f55776896a2e33239c2954519f605e-Abstract-Conference.html">;papers</a>; that address the problem of designing efficient differentially private algorithms for clustering that can scale to massive datasets. Our goal is, moreover, to offer scalability to large scale input datasets, even when the target number of centers, <em>;k</em>;, is large. </p>; <p>; We work in the <a href="https://www.cs.umd.edu/~gasarch/MPC/mpc.pdf">;massively parallel computation</a>; (MPC) model, which is a computation model representative of modern distributed computation architectures. The model consists of several machines, each holding only part of the input data, that work together with the goal of solving a global problem while minimizing the amount of communication between machines. We present a <a href="https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper_files/paper/2022/hash/43f55776896a2e33239c2954519f605e-Abstract-Conference.html">;differentially private constant factor approximation algorithm</a>; for <em>;k</em>;-means that only requires a constant number of rounds of synchronization. Our algorithm builds upon our <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3534678.3539409">;previous work</a>; on the problem (with code <a href="https://github.com/google-research/google-research/tree/master/hst_clustering">;available here</a>;), which was the first differentially-private clustering algorithm with provable approximation guarantees that can work in the MPC model. </p>; <p>; The DP constant factor approximation algorithm drastically improves on the previous work using a two phase approach. In an initial phase it computes a crude approximation to “seed” the second phase, which consists of a more sophisticated distributed algorithm. Equipped with the first-step approximation, the second phase relies on results from the <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3406325.3451022">;Coreset literature</a>; to subsample a relevant set of input points and find a good differentially private clustering solution for the input points. We then prove that this solution generalizes with approximately the same guarantee to the entire input. </p>; <br />; <h2>;Vaccination search insights via DP clustering</h2>; <p>; We then apply these advances in differentially private clustering to real-world applications. One example is our application of our differentially-private clustering solution for publishing COVID vaccine-related queries, while providing strong privacy protections for the users. </p>; <p>; The goal of <a href="https://google-research.github.io/vaccination-search-insights/?">;Vaccination Search Insights</a>; (VSI) is to help public health decision makers (health authorities, government agencies and nonprofits) identify and respond to communities' information needs regarding COVID vaccines. In order to achieve this, the tool allows users to explore at different geolocation granularities (zip-code, county and state level in the US) the top themes searched by users regarding COVID queries. In particular, the tool visualizes statistics on trending queries rising in interest in a given locale and time. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjLB2pSTmTxFG_h03ZLJf22m2DhRwjo31ksW7yxde1TLwhqT1nUqhG4ryiEWs8SGwhBAJvGY9Urt6BuhUumdAQ7IHpEHNsECa53M98cXTvucOquUwGlKnq-cXfdryCJB7U3zR9859vZrrnh5ufwfWSE0OIlNUzN_0e0g7dggUHY-AxwtlIx5AF4Risviw/s800/COVIDSearchStats.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="320" data-original-width="800" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjLB2pSTmTxFG_h03ZLJf22m2DhRwjo31ksW7yxde1TLwhqT1nUqhG4ryiEWs8SGwhBAJvGY9Urt6BuhUumdAQ7IHpEHNsECa53M98cXTvucOquUwGlKnq-cXfdryCJB7U3zR9859vZrrnh5ufwfWSE0OIlNUzN_0e0g7dggUHY-AxwtlIx5AF4Risviw/s16000/COVIDSearchStats.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Screenshot of the output of the tool. Displayed on the left, the top searches related to Covid vaccines during the period Oct 10-16 2022. On the right, the queries that have had rising importance during the same period and compared to the previous week.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; To better help identifying the themes of the trending searches, the tool clusters the search queries based on their semantic similarity. This is done by applying a custom-designed <em>;k</em>;-means–based algorithm run over search data that has been anonymized using the DP Gaussian mechanism to add noise and remove low-count queries (thus resulting in a differentially clustering). The method ensures strong differential privacy guarantees for the protection of the user data. </p>; <p>; This tool provided fine-grained data on COVID vaccine perception in the population at unprecedented scales of granularity, something that is especially relevant to understand the needs of the marginalized communities disproportionately affected by COVID. This project highlights the impact of our investment in research in differential privacy, and unsupervised ML methods. We are looking to other important areas where we can apply these clustering techniques to help guide decision making around global health challenges, like search queries on <a href="https://blog.google/technology/health/dr-von-nguyens-temperature-check-on-public-health/">;climate change–related challenges</a>; such as air quality or extreme heat. </p>; <br />; Manyika, SVP Google Research and Technology & Society, and Jeff Dean, Chief Scientist, Google DeepMind and Google Research</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjUde5cQAPm8frw1OO3Ub-QIx91GGpY3crqacseMxvbkJ55GMmjma-dqjEmxg8XtAJpSEYvyVWsFagmNVLzugwLWJiQ6OHPm0c1yDgIgXzTHRRF4NpoOJRl5p75u3O11uYuOmPNJW97Xyciox0OJni48f3MrMGmAPqVudm9mtsUUtGaCvt9vIQrc6h3NA/s1200/GoogleIO.jpg" style="display: none;" />; <p>; Wednesday, May 10th was an exciting day for the <a href="https://research.google">;Google Research</a>; community as we watched the results of months and years of our foundational and applied work get announced on the <a href="https://io.google/2023/">;Google I/O</a>; stage. With the quick pace of announcements on stage, it can be difficult to convey the substantial effort and unique innovations that underlie the technologies we presented. So today, we're excited to reveal more about the research efforts behind some of the many compelling announcements at <a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL590L5WQmH8dAqv03RCMbZrbzxqCn6W3O">;this year's I/O</a>;. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <br />; <h2>;PaLM 2 </h2>; <p>; Our next-generation large language model (LLM), <a href="https://ai.google/discover/palm2">;PaLM 2</a>;, is built on advances in <a href="https://www.deepmind.com/publications/an-empirical-analysis-of-compute-optimal-large-language-model-training">;compute-optimal scaling</a>;, <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.11416">;scaled instruction-fine tuning</a>; and <a href="https://ai.google/static/documents/palm2techreport.pdf">;improved dataset mixture</a>;. By fine-tuning and instruction-tuning the model for different purposes, we have been able to integrate state-of-the-art capabilities into over 25 Google products and features, where it is already helping to inform, assist and delight users. For example: </p>; <ul>; <li>;<a href="https://bard.google.com/">;Bard</a>; is an early experiment that lets you collaborate with generative AI and helps to boost productivity, accelerate ideas and fuel curiosity. It builds on <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/02/google-research-2022-beyond-algorithms.html">;advances in deep learning efficiency</a>; and leverages <a href="https://ai.google/static/documents/google-about-bard.pdf">;reinforcement learning from human feedback</a>; to provide more relevant responses and increase the model's ability to follow instructions. Bard is now available in 180 countries, where users can interact with it in English, Japanese and Korean, and thanks to the multilingual capabilities afforded by PaLM 2, support for 40 languages is coming soon. </li>;<li>;With <a href="https://blog.google/products/search/generative-ai-search/">;Search Generative Experience</a>; we're taking more of the work out of searching, so you'll be able to understand a topic faster, uncover new viewpoints and insights, and get things done more easily. As part of this experiment, you'll see an AI-powered snapshot of key information to consider, with links to dig deeper. </li>;<li>;<a href="https://makersuite.google.com/">;MakerSuite</a>; is an easy-to-use prototyping environment for the <a href="https://developers.generativeai.google/products/palm">;PaLM API</a>;, powered by PaLM 2. In fact, internal user engagement with early prototypes of MakerSuite accelerated the development of our PaLM 2 model itself. MakerSuite grew out of research focused on prompting tools, or tools explicitly designed for customizing and controlling LLMs. This line of research includes <a href="https://research.google/pubs/pub51353/">;PromptMaker</a>; (precursor to MakerSuite), and <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3491102.3517582">;AI Chains</a>; and <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3491101.3519729">;PromptChainer</a>; (one of the first research efforts demonstrating the utility of LLM chaining). </li>;<li>;Project <a href="https://thoughtful.withgoogle.com/about">;Tailwind</a>; also made use of early research prototypes of MakerSuite to develop features to help writers and researchers explore ideas and improve their prose; its AI-first notebook prototype used PaLM 2 to allow users to ask questions of the model grounded in documents they define. </li>;<li>;<a href="https://sites.research.google/med-palm/">;Med-PaLM 2</a>; is our state-of-the-art medical LLM, built on PaLM 2. Med-PaLM 2 achieved <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09617">;86.5% performance</a>; on US Medical Licensing Exam–style questions, illustrating its exciting potential for health. We're now exploring multimodal capabilities to synthesize inputs like X-rays. </li>;<li>;<a href="https://ai.google/discover/foundation-models/">;Codey</a>; is a version of PaLM 2 fine-tuned on source code to function as a developer assistant. It supports a broad range of <a href="https://ai.google/static/documents/palm2techreport.pdf">;Code AI</a>; features, including code completions, code explanation, bug fixing, source code migration, error explanations, and more. Codey is available through our trusted tester program via IDEs (<a href="https://blog.google/technology/developers/google-colab-ai-coding-features/">;Colab</a>;, <a href="https://developer.android.com/studio/preview/studio-bot">;Android Studio</a>;, <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/application-modernization/introducing-duet-ai-for-google-cloud">;Duet AI for Cloud</a>;, <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2023/05/10/googles-firebase-gets-ai-extensions-opens-up-its-marketplace/">;Firebase</a>;) and via a <a href="https://developers.generativeai.google/products/palm">;3P-facing API</a>;. </li>; </ul>; <p>; Perhaps even more exciting for developers, we have opened up the <a href="https://makersuite.google.com/">;PaLM APIs & MakerSuite</a>; to provide the community opportunities to innovate using this groundbreaking technology. </p>; -->; <br />; <h2>;ARCore and the Scene Semantic API</h2>; <p>; Among the new features of <a href="https://developers.google.com/ar">;ARCore</a>; announced by the AR team at I/O, the <a href="https://developers.google.com/ar/develop/scene-semantics">;Scene Semantic API</a>; can recognize pixel-wise semantics in an outdoor scene. This helps users create custom AR experiences based on the features in the surrounding area. This API is empowered by the outdoor semantic segmentation model, leveraging our recent works around the <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.02611">;DeepLab</a>; architecture and an egocentric outdoor scene understanding dataset. The latest ARCore release also includes an improved monocular depth model that provides higher accuracy in outdoor scenes. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjGnl1lYcfkaoqmwIOqb1R8bojq_bbIgiGYC9cMuTGO5hqwsrdXHhGaHIBlfAPwTob-KpyVXUFt-8_NPu1GPhZgmbyfT-ILRDmn980P_tkb0jfwzNNw0cannsvSNTiMyRcntVJ9AyjfnGT5Q4ZBBotOx4MJPOOCF57Ejs0VN1evKjubZQYpyX_NfMtx4A/s486/image3.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="486" data-original-width="242" height="400" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjGnl1lYcfkaoqmwIOqb1R8bojq_bbIgiGYC9cMuTGO5hqwsrdXHhGaHIBlfAPwTob-KpyVXUFt-8_NPu1GPhZgmbyfT-ILRDmn980P_tkb0jfwzNNw0cannsvSNTiMyRcntVJ9AyjfnGT5Q4ZBBotOx4MJPOOCF57Ejs0VN1evKjubZQYpyX_NfMtx4A/w199-h400/image3.gif" width="199" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Scene Semantics API uses DeepLab-based semantic segmentation model to provide accurate pixel-wise labels in a scene outdoors.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <h2>;Chirp</h2>; <p>; <a href="https://cloud.google.com/speech-to-text/v2/docs/chirp-model">;Chirp</a>; is Google's family of state-of-the-art <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/03/universal-speech-model-usm-state-of-art.html">;Universal Speech Models</a>; trained on 12 million hours of speech to enable automatic speech recognition (ASR) for 100+ languages. The models can perform ASR on under-resourced languages, such as Amharic, Cebuano, and Assamese, in addition to widely spoken languages like English and Mandarin. Chirp is able to cover such a wide variety of languages by leveraging <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01037">;self-supervised learning on unlabeled multilingual dataset with fine-tuning on a smaller set of labeled data</a>;. Chirp is now available in the Google Cloud <a href="https://cloud.google.com/speech-to-text">;Speech-to-Text API</a>;, allowing users to perform inference on the model through a simple interface. You can get started with Chirp <a href="https://cloud.google.com/speech-to-text/v2/docs/chirp-model">;here</a>;. </p>; <div style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhtWnj_lXrnnMX5wnXJoWwpRg34v-MyHuSepuvVK4MZfWgbBhGgcMZXPFoSBvS8RIccX9Fes4ASD4mhjrQYyLzZRoaGZjqBrNSfFRChVh1rQ3Disr2q9iO0tiPkHwf3JiReP_0E1nfsS4MWbQwOzxwBHGCX29IhxooTSqw8qhXvQAyoIG9v_SVX6YOHPQ/s591/image7.gif">;<img border="0" data-original-height="250" data-original-width="591" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhtWnj_lXrnnMX5wnXJoWwpRg34v-MyHuSepuvVK4MZfWgbBhGgcMZXPFoSBvS8RIccX9Fes4ASD4mhjrQYyLzZRoaGZjqBrNSfFRChVh1rQ3Disr2q9iO0tiPkHwf3JiReP_0E1nfsS4MWbQwOzxwBHGCX29IhxooTSqw8qhXvQAyoIG9v_SVX6YOHPQ/s16000/image7.gif" />;</a>;</div>; <br />; <h2>;MusicLM</h2>; <p>; At I/O, we launched <a href="https://google-research.github.io/seanet/musiclm/examples/">;MusicLM, a text-to-music model</a>; that generates 20 seconds of music from a text prompt. <a href="https://aitestkitchen.withgoogle.com/experiments/music-lm">;You can try it yourself on AI Test Kitchen</a>;, or see it featured during the I/O preshow, where electronic musician and composer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Deacon">;Dan Deacon</a>; used MusicLM in his performance. </p>; <p>; MusicLM, which consists of models powered by <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/10/audiolm-language-modeling-approach-to.html">;AudioLM</a>; and <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.12415">;MuLAN</a>;, can make music (from text, humming, images or video) and musical accompaniments to singing. AudioLM generates high quality audio with long-term consistency. It maps audio to a sequence of discrete tokens and casts audio generation as a language modeling task. To synthesize longer outputs efficiently, it used a novel approach we've developed called <a href="https://google-research.github.io/seanet/soundstorm/examples/">;SoundStorm</a>;. </p>; <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhiTUOKJuyb19L8ukNhdv51q7M4cMXSJbSnp1n9pd_-vRHzOAW3pENKYWDyBoPKYIN-K9UpduTbXjqQZ3IX5jwtrp0YNu13dZuYC2uIplzl_oSyLDXAhfO6L1kAaXdJXIWWhsGTqJQb-O_0JZ18E4lVNDaT23gMBg9Jcu2r4N_ofkUckaIMSTW0vEJkMQ/s1927/keywordhero.png" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="964" data-original-width="1927" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhiTUOKJuyb19L8ukNhdv51q7M4cMXSJbSnp1n9pd_-vRHzOAW3pENKYWDyBoPKYIN-K9UpduTbXjqQZ3IX5jwtrp0YNu13dZuYC2uIplzl_oSyLDXAhfO6L1kAaXdJXIWWhsGTqJQb-O_0JZ18E4lVNDaT23gMBg9Jcu2r4N_ofkUckaIMSTW0vEJkMQ/s16000/keywordhero.png" />;</a>;</div>; <br />; <h2>;Universal Translator dubbing</h2>; <p>; Our dubbing efforts leverage dozens of ML technologies to translate the full expressive range of video content, making videos accessible to audiences across the world. These technologies have been used to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S-iIV5Oo0n0">;dub videos</a>; across a variety of products and content types, including educational content, advertising campaigns, and creator content, with more to come. We use deep learning technology to achieve <a href="https://developers.googleblog.com/2022/12/improving-video-voice-dubbing-through-deep-learning.html">;voice preservation and lip matching</a>; and enable high-quality video translation. We've built this product to include human review for quality, safety checks to help prevent misuse, and we make it accessible only to authorized partners. </p>; <br />; <h2>;AI for global societal good</h2>; <p>; We are applying our AI technologies to solve some of the biggest global challenges, like mitigating climate change, adapting to a warming planet and improving human health and wellbeing. For example: </p>; <ul>; <li>;Traffic engineers use our Green Light recommendations to reduce stop-and-go traffic at intersections and improve the flow of traffic in cities from Bangalore to Rio de Janeiro and Hamburg. Green Light models each intersection, analyzing traffic patterns to develop recommendations that make traffic lights more efficient — for example, by better synchronizing timing between adjacent lights, or adjusting the “green time” for a given street and direction. </li>;<li>;We've also expanded global coverage on the <a href="https://sites.research.google/floods/l/0/0/3">;Flood Hub</a>; to 80 countries, as part of our efforts to predict riverine floods and alert people who are about to be impacted before disaster strikes. Our <a href="https://sites.research.google/floodforecasting">;flood forecasting efforts</a>; rely on <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2019/09/an-inside-look-at-flood-forecasting.html">;hydrological models</a>; informed by satellite observations, weather forecasts and in-situ measurements. <div style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgqlBPlwDoD8Fa-Kmh1PfWb2St5CytGcSHNNNuPjvmACdbXZA7xdWV1cQm_ucjvazfm091eVtZcyFteSrXMLrYWDEAjB7tcDY4xoxu3CMSAK0e4J2d6FG1uIBj_I2udbWNwFHHAoeLwkyco4rdCey-0adK5rZBLw1tjAtFzkhheifFsjXRBMxGF6to10w/s1672/image5.png">;<img border="0" data-original-height="713" data-original-width="1672" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgqlBPlwDoD8Fa-Kmh1PfWb2St5CytGcSHNNNuPjvmACdbXZA7xdWV1cQm_ucjvazfm091eVtZcyFteSrXMLrYWDEAjB7tcDY4xoxu3CMSAK0e4J2d6FG1uIBj_I2udbWNwFHHAoeLwkyco4rdCey-0adK5rZBLw1tjAtFzkhheifFsjXRBMxGF6to10w/s16000/image5.png" />;</a>;</div>; </li>; </ul>; <br />; <h2>;Technologies for inclusive and fair ML applications</h2>; <p>; With our continued investment in AI technologies, we are emphasizing responsible AI development with the goal of making our models and tools useful and impactful while also ensuring fairness, safety and alignment with our <a href="https://ai.google/principles/">;AI Principles</a>;. Some of these efforts were highlighted at I/O, including: </p>; <ul>; <li>;The release of the <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/05/consensus-and-subjectivity-of-skin-tone_15.html">;Monk Skin Tone Examples (MST-E) Dataset</a>; to help practitioners gain a deeper understanding of the MST scale and train human annotators for more consistent, inclusive, and meaningful skin tone annotations. You can read more about this and other developments on our <a href="https://skintone.google/">;website</a>;. This is an advancement on the open source release of the <a href="https://blog.google/products/search/monk-skin-tone-scale/">;Monk Skin Tone (MST) Scale</a>; we launched last year to enable developers to build products that are more inclusive and that better represent their diverse users. </li>;<li>;A <a href="https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/asl-fingerspelling/overview/description">;new Kaggle competition</a>; (open until August 10th) in which the ML community is tasked with creating a model that can quickly and accurately identify American Sign Language (ASL) fingerspelling — where each letter of a word is spelled out in ASL rapidly using a single hand, rather than using the specific signs for entire words — and translate it into written text. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q3xKB3dfvtA">;fingerspelling Kaggle competition</a>;, which features a song from <a href="https://www.deafandloud.com/">;Sean Forbes</a>;, a deaf musician and rapper. We also <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WC9x3jp_nV8">;showcased at I/O</a>; the winning algorithm from the prior year's competition powers <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=edu.gatech.popsignai&hl=en_US&gl=US">;PopSign</a>;, an ASL learning app for parents of deaf or hard of hearing children created by Georgia Tech and Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT). </li>; </ul>; <br />; <h2>;Building the future of AI together</h2>; <p>; It's inspiring to be part of a community of so many talented individuals who are leading the way in developing state-of-the-art technologies, responsible AI approaches and exciting user experiences. We are in the midst of a period of incredible and transformative change for AI. Stay tuned for more updates about the ways in which the Google Research community is boldly exploring the frontiers of these technologies and using them responsibly to benefit people's lives around the world. We hope you're as excited as we are about the future of AI technologies and we invite you to engage with our teams through the references, sites and tools that we've highlighted here. scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="User Experience">;</category>;<title type="text">;Resolving code review comments with ML</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by Alexander Frömmgen, Staff Software Engineer, and Lera Kharatyan, Senior Software Engineer, Core Systems & Experiences</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjoK3FH1StJnuqrj0gTExqLUxNkVfwRVmiG9tbCNUDV2I5295yqrPlw0L4hRHJmsruvZBIa_FqAFvJfwW7VU4XvxDU4ZweaW6ehENeU7-BLJaLVGPPtn-25cme5qTUldd11YigkAj6Ks9Tif6J3MePey_Gn3cAp3nQf9LMmVy4Eg3yF0qyBZPUKfYJYLw/s2000/comments2code.png" style="display: none;" />; <p>; Code-change reviews are a critical part of the software development process at scale, <a href="https://sback.it/publications/icse2018seip.pdf">;taking</a>; a significant amount of the code authors' and the code reviewers' time. As part of this process, the reviewer inspects the proposed code and asks the author for code changes through comments written in natural language. At Google, we see <a href="https://sback.it/publications/icse2018seip.pdf">;millions of reviewer comments</a>; per year, and authors require an average of ~60 minutes <a href="https://research.google/pubs/pub49446/">;active shepherding time</a>; between sending changes for review and finally submitting the change. In our measurements, the required active work time that the code author must do to address reviewer comments grows almost linearly with the number of comments. However, with machine learning (ML), we have an opportunity to automate and streamline the code review process, eg, by proposing code changes based on a comment's text. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; Today, we describe our application of recent advances in large sequence models (using the <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/05/large-sequence-models-for-software.html">;DIDACT methodology</a>;) in a real-world setting to automatically resolve code review comments in the day-to-day development workflow at Google. As of today, code-change authors at Google address a substantial amount of reviewer comments by applying an ML-suggested edit. We expect that to reduce time spent on code reviews by hundreds of thousands of hours annually at Google scale. Unsolicited, very positive feedback highlights that the impact of ML-suggested code edits increases Googlers' productivity and allows them to focus on more creative and complex tasks. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Predicting the code edit</h2>; <p>; We started by training a model that predicts code edits needed to address reviewer comments. The model is pre-trained on various coding tasks and related developer activities (eg, renaming a variable, repairing a broken build, editing a file). It's then fine-tuned for this specific task with reviewed code changes, the reviewer comments, and the edits the author performed to address those comments. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgRR4C9paw916JEuwW9jTXjFBTt9ii4KEnnXBw2HgxY5MR9muFW3IdJLloAlRV-7AP3Nd8Jg1q633KQS6zfXDlPZlIV8c7KIp9iXgsM2GHJV_iv4e5mCrUhRrT2LFNBpuSFGTLzKDk6w56Km_jOOkWMMdEZlMadlwBDYVGnztFOPk1mo828sWEpUF1O-g/s1523/figure1.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="700" data-original-width="1523" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgRR4C9paw916JEuwW9jTXjFBTt9ii4KEnnXBw2HgxY5MR9muFW3IdJLloAlRV-7AP3Nd8Jg1q633KQS6zfXDlPZlIV8c7KIp9iXgsM2GHJV_iv4e5mCrUhRrT2LFNBpuSFGTLzKDk6w56Km_jOOkWMMdEZlMadlwBDYVGnztFOPk1mo828sWEpUF1O-g/s16000/figure1.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;An example of an ML-suggested edit of refactorings that are spread within the code.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; Google uses a <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/2854146">;monorepo</a>;, a single repository for all of its software artifacts, which allows our training dataset to include all unrestricted code used to build Google's most recent software, as well as previous versions. </p>; <p>; To improve the model quality, we iterated on the training dataset. For example, we compared the model performance for datasets with a single reviewer comment per file to datasets with multiple comments per file, and experimented with classifiers to clean up the training data based on a small, curated dataset to choose the model with the best offline precision and recall metrics. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Serving infrastructure and user experience</h2>; <p>; We designed and implemented the feature on top of the trained model, focusing on the overall user experience and developer efficiency. As part of this, we explored different user experience (UX) alternatives through a series of user studies. We then refined the feature based on insights from an internal beta (ie, a test of the feature in development) including user feedback (eg, a “Was this helpful?” button next to the suggested edit). </p>; <p>; The final model was calibrated for a target <a href="https://developers.google.com/machine-learning/crash-course/classification/precision-and-recall">;precision</a>; of 50%. That is, we tuned the model and the suggestions filtering, so that 50% of suggested edits on our evaluation dataset are correct. In general, increasing the target precision reduces the number of shown suggested edits, and decreasing the target precision leads to more incorrect suggested edits. Incorrect suggested edits take the developers time and reduce the developers' trust in the feature. We found that a target precision of 50% provides a good balance. </p>; <p>; At a high level, for every new reviewer comment, we generate the model input in the same format that is used for training, query the model, and generate the suggested code edit. If the model is confident in the prediction and a few additional heuristics are satisfied, we send the suggested edit to downstream systems. The downstream systems, ie, the code review frontend and the integrated development environment (IDE), expose the suggested edits to the user and log user interactions, such as preview and apply events. A dedicated pipeline collects these logs and generates aggregate insights, eg, the overall acceptance rates as reported in this blog post. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi5csoDiwO-5vBxy3C4hFSW1urE791VDmpjuM2XyuVQvgMzjwrfqdwIKyJaOffDGEI4X3Y1cjTwP0kiRudNVHB6IKbkzo7znabCW16vsmhyOYyeXFOC24RYXIr406expAnjSRiid883LWa1hRiEXjMa2j5SqvTWFUeucRZ4Bjw9moOo7D_zg1pmGE02-g/s1250/figure%202c.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="465" data-original-width="1250" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi5csoDiwO-5vBxy3C4hFSW1urE791VDmpjuM2XyuVQvgMzjwrfqdwIKyJaOffDGEI4X3Y1cjTwP0kiRudNVHB6IKbkzo7znabCW16vsmhyOYyeXFOC24RYXIr406expAnjSRiid883LWa1hRiEXjMa2j5SqvTWFUeucRZ4Bjw9moOo7D_zg1pmGE02-g/s16000/figure%202c.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Architecture of the ML-suggested edits infrastructure. We process code and infrastructure from multiple services, get the model predictions and surface the predictions in the code review tool and IDE.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; The developer interacts with the ML-suggested edits in the code review tool and the IDE. Based on insights from the user studies, the integration into the code review tool is most suitable for a streamlined review experience. The IDE integration provides additional functionality and supports 3-way merging of the ML-suggested edits (left in the figure below) in case of conflicting local changes on top of the reviewed code state (right) into the merge result (center). </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgceQpRBQ0ooZGNUvGgc1j1qnF8YwJaVGmhUF2KUD8F_KlLJVgzoo-VGcJsIRykGR-flujvuXB83a61cVz88tZHKsJPb8h9tLmoI4LDizmHvaSzRhwcQpxmQZtLI12ckyWJmxl9yhqiFYmHF7oKoBEYSJhqiyhVRtYp-nFBB5RH2VLH3Jtauls4ti1Tmw/s958/figure%203%20(25%25).gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="436" data-original-width="958" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgceQpRBQ0ooZGNUvGgc1j1qnF8YwJaVGmhUF2KUD8F_KlLJVgzoo-VGcJsIRykGR-flujvuXB83a61cVz88tZHKsJPb8h9tLmoI4LDizmHvaSzRhwcQpxmQZtLI12ckyWJmxl9yhqiFYmHF7oKoBEYSJhqiyhVRtYp-nFBB5RH2VLH3Jtauls4ti1Tmw/s16000/figure%203%20(25%25).gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;3-way-merge UX in IDE.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Results</h2>; <p>; Offline evaluations indicate that the model addresses 52% of comments with a target precision of 50%. The online metrics of the beta and the full internal launch confirm these offline metrics, ie, we see model suggestions above our target model confidence for around 50% of all relevant reviewer comments. 40% to 50% of all previewed suggested edits are applied by code authors. </p>; <p>; We used the “not helpful” feedback during the beta to identify recurring failure patterns of the model. We implemented serving-time heuristics to filter these and, thus, reduce the number of shown incorrect predictions. With these changes, we traded quantity for quality and observed an increased real-world acceptance rate. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhyN4DWxW8l5pkxQs0zvbrINGkJSUWnLizahvVbmanqdh0KlnxH4mTHVtKDjNn29fq8oJ35BQNYeeF8p_YURKz2qwS7LwAVoBZflochjmcTVJlag1UrSsaY-DLTDB9H0tJTi1emA6nWstqomACKOeVS4DSANGDl-UWpgXfu-PgliUIMFtUOgi7OyUNg2A/s1753/figure%204%20(50%25).gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="802" data-original-width="1753" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhyN4DWxW8l5pkxQs0zvbrINGkJSUWnLizahvVbmanqdh0KlnxH4mTHVtKDjNn29fq8oJ35BQNYeeF8p_YURKz2qwS7LwAVoBZflochjmcTVJlag1UrSsaY-DLTDB9H0tJTi1emA6nWstqomACKOeVS4DSANGDl-UWpgXfu-PgliUIMFtUOgi7OyUNg2A/s16000/figure%204%20(50%25).gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Code review tool UX. The suggestion is shown as part of the comment and can be previewed, applied and rated as helpful or not helpful.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; Our beta launch showed a <em>;discoverability challenge</em>;: code authors only previewed ~20% of all generated suggested edits. We modified the UX and introduced a prominent “Show ML-edit” button (see the figure above) next to the reviewer comment, leading to an overall preview rate of ~40% at launch. We additionally found that suggested edits in the code review tool are often not applicable due to conflicting changes that the author did during the review process. We addressed this with a button in the code review tool that opens the IDE in a merge view for the suggested edit. We now observe that more than 70% of these are applied in the code review tool and fewer than 30% are applied in the IDE. All these changes allowed us to increase the overall fraction of reviewer comments that are addressed with an ML-suggested edit by a factor of 2 from beta to the full internal launch. At Google scale, these results help automate the resolution of hundreds of thousands of comments each year. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgbb5VXmcCaqT7-jtdVBB57Jzb41KhulYqquTk1OAG35-hM-ztMZvQAzh69E-IA-fJMJCkPJ9v7altTmAU9IzkfJrhxqtZdYT7sF-swZ9ThsiOpK5sD2B1bMfxaQlwFKy7dEqEEgDxnF2FOnnMteUgilDPQcvxciDGpaqh4bRfkds5XIQq9-qaZEZkZyw/s1920/figure%207.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="887" data-original-width="1920" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgbb5VXmcCaqT7-jtdVBB57Jzb41KhulYqquTk1OAG35-hM-ztMZvQAzh69E-IA-fJMJCkPJ9v7altTmAU9IzkfJrhxqtZdYT7sF-swZ9ThsiOpK5sD2B1bMfxaQlwFKy7dEqEEgDxnF2FOnnMteUgilDPQcvxciDGpaqh4bRfkds5XIQq9-qaZEZkZyw/s16000/figure%207.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Suggestions filtering funnel.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; We see ML-suggested edits addressing a wide range of reviewer comments in production. This includes simple localized refactorings and refactorings that are spread within the code, as shown in the examples throughout the blog post above. The feature addresses longer and less formally-worded comments that require code generation, refactorings and imports. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi8d6n1irF1I8_8vkOGByJYA_S5K1kxMguPNr9Z212V0yJvTX46rfj7HZT0ggOfcpJPHobT7UQttP_86gxRsPCbBbiuwMKfrzktVCccBTQXWe8l5a_ezmZJMQQ0yl8tXPThkxQR_yV2JejcpFXwhZ0U_ssbKyVcfaLKk_KErzWJ1Dszu0gasvsuTS0gVQ/s1479/figure%205c.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="651" data-original-width="1479" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi8d6n1irF1I8_8vkOGByJYA_S5K1kxMguPNr9Z212V0yJvTX46rfj7HZT0ggOfcpJPHobT7UQttP_86gxRsPCbBbiuwMKfrzktVCccBTQXWe8l5a_ezmZJMQQ0yl8tXPThkxQR_yV2JejcpFXwhZ0U_ssbKyVcfaLKk_KErzWJ1Dszu0gasvsuTS0gVQ/s16000/figure%205c.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Example of a suggestion for a longer and less formally worded comment that requires code generation, refactorings and imports.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; The model can also respond to complex comments and produce extensive code edits (shown below). The generated test case follows the existing unit test pattern, while changing the details as described in the comment. Additionally, the edit suggests a comprehensive name for the test reflecting the test semantics. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgPJQaVUZNW7KVuLtF1n_Gxhe1wg8QcElAABAp4AQH-B6mnt5N2-xZqEnK5VnEoy5eqXrdwR__xICAHDUYxb3wC25M_XA7gdJCN0l4mavhLNSxzC4lUqXL-7x3FD4M9SNEvgdmLzN5jcX727V4QEgAxn36BN_R7l4HQmjzwG6e9v6Vq1HzFKy1s8H01SA/s1497/figure%206c.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="648" data-original-width="1497" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgPJQaVUZNW7KVuLtF1n_Gxhe1wg8QcElAABAp4AQH-B6mnt5N2-xZqEnK5VnEoy5eqXrdwR__xICAHDUYxb3wC25M_XA7gdJCN0l4mavhLNSxzC4lUqXL-7x3FD4M9SNEvgdmLzN5jcX727V4QEgAxn36BN_R7l4HQmjzwG6e9v6Vq1HzFKy1s8H01SA/s16000/figure%206c.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Example of the model's ability to respond to complex comments and produce extensive code edits.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Conclusion and future work</h2>; <p>; In this post, we introduced an ML-assistance feature to reduce the time spent on code review related changes. At the moment, a substantial amount of all actionable code review comments on supported languages are addressed with applied ML-suggested edits at Google. A 12-week A/B experiment across all Google developers will further measure the impact of the feature on the overall developer productivity. </p>; <p>; We are working on improvements throughout the whole stack. This includes increasing the quality and recall of the model and building a more streamlined experience for the developer with improved discoverability throughout the review process. As part of this, we are investigating the option of showing suggested edits to the reviewer while they draft comments and expanding the feature into the IDE to enable code-change authors to get suggested code edits for natural-language commands. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>; <em>;This is the work of many people in Google Core Systems & Experiences team, Google Research, and DeepMind. scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Deep Learning">;</category>;<category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Security and Privacy">;</category>;<title type="text">;Making ML models differentially private: Best practices and open challenges</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by Natalia Ponomareva and Alex Kurakin, Staff Software Engineers, Google Research</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhqMCb-nNfoCncADD29b0YyxB4wN8bOhRph7pJBGzKyYc1bvdZ10VC3RkyUCJBopmvukjXJnZiJyiZ5ZIPyIW66ZfrYmBoJFrxx35T8OrL_HmNr4YIKzBS5y6Ej24f1Mjsu-IqH5ECyzPBRKDRtoGgQhoKoOpILElqHDIGsn9SiI-7x58qc_nbtQ1JZ1A/s320/DPfy%20hero.gif" style="display: none;" />; <p>; Large machine learning (ML) models are ubiquitous in modern applications: from <a href="https://workspace.google.com/blog/identity-and-security/an-overview-of-gmails-spam-filters">;spam filters</a>; to <a href="https://developers.google.com/machine-learning/recommendation/overview/types">;recommender systems</a>; and <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/07/look-and-talk-natural-conversations.html">;virtual assistants</a>;. These models achieve remarkable performance partially due to the abundance of available training data. However, these data can sometimes contain private information, including personal identifiable information, copyright material, etc. Therefore, protecting the privacy of the training data is critical to practical, applied ML. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_privacy">;Differential Privacy</a>; (DP) is one of the most widely accepted technologies that allows reasoning about data anonymization in a formal way. In the context of an ML model, DP can guarantee that each individual user's contribution will not result in a significantly different model. A model's privacy guarantees are characterized by a tuple (<em>;ε</em>;, <em>;δ</em>;), where smaller values of both represent stronger DP guarantees and better privacy. </p>; <p>; While there are successful <a href="https://research.google/pubs/pub52351/">;examples</a>; of <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/02/federated-learning-with-formal.html">;protecting training data</a>; using DP, obtaining good utility with differentially private ML (DP-ML) techniques can be challenging. First, there are inherent privacy/computation tradeoffs that may limit a model's utility. Further, DP-ML models often require architectural and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperparameter_optimization">;hyperparameter</a>; tuning, and guidelines on how to do this effectively are limited or difficult to find. Finally, non-rigorous privacy reporting makes it challenging to compare and choose the best DP methods. </p>; <p>; In “<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00654">;How to DP-fy ML: A Practical Guide to Machine Learning with Differential Privacy</a>;”, to appear in the <em>;<a href="https://www.jair.org/index.php/jair">;Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research</a>;</em>;, we discuss the current state of DP-ML research. We provide an overview of common techniques for obtaining DP-ML models and discuss research, engineering challenges, mitigation techniques and current open questions. We will present tutorials based on this work at <a href="https://icml.cc/Conferences/2023">;ICML 2023</a>; and <a href="https://kdd.org/kdd2023/">;KDD 2023</a>;. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;DP-ML methods</h2>; <p>; DP can be introduced during the ML model development process in three places: (1) at the input data level, (2) during training, or (3) at inference. Each option provides privacy protections at different stages of the ML development process, with the weakest being when DP is introduced at the prediction level and the strongest being when introduced at the input level. Making the input data differentially private means that any model that is trained on this data will also have DP guarantees. When introducing DP during the training, only that particular model has DP guarantees. DP at the prediction level means that only the model's predictions are protected, but the model itself is not differentially private. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhm6JbnVKbvGHMOesXYhP2AWZqVWeYqZGL4Hp4xruQmLzGZNv_Pb0tweOOmSznicm06Fb0Dk6G4HpE5hp2hOeAY0BWCO04rL1w_tdE5JC3jBbmPzMRpGQgf9z1jYYszQyltM3rvXaHLG7__JnePH9MEVG_YTSFYEQdYHQUTJXxVjzyCjREw0Bj4I4It3w/s1821/image2.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="446" data-original-width="1821" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhm6JbnVKbvGHMOesXYhP2AWZqVWeYqZGL4Hp4xruQmLzGZNv_Pb0tweOOmSznicm06Fb0Dk6G4HpE5hp2hOeAY0BWCO04rL1w_tdE5JC3jBbmPzMRpGQgf9z1jYYszQyltM3rvXaHLG7__JnePH9MEVG_YTSFYEQdYHQUTJXxVjzyCjREw0Bj4I4It3w/s16000/image2.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;The task of introducing DP gets progressively easier from the left to right.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; DP is commonly introduced during training (DP-training). <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.00654.pdf">;Gradient noise injection</a>; methods, like <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1607.00133">;DP-SGD</a>; or <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.00039">;DP-FTRL</a>;, and their extensions are currently the most practical methods for achieving DP guarantees in complex models like large deep neural networks. </p>; <p>; DP-SGD builds off of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent">;stochastic gradient descent</a>; (SGD) optimizer with two modifications: (1) per-example gradients are clipped to a certain norm to limit sensitivity (the influence of an individual example on the overall model), which is a slow and computationally intensive process, and (2) a noisy gradient update is formed by taking aggregated gradients and adding noise that is proportional to the sensitivity and the strength of privacy guarantees. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgQqxkabmVXlVWrPH4rEop_ZFxMo_DtkzllZq3JIpstNNxAxutrZe-kS24Vqi1b2r4BvF1zEP3hpZGEvoExnJHKqgnREGcgTJWSjmfglItZAa_ZHLrsTTRvLBxY4z6nmeJoT1ptEnM9dkM82Iq8_FCA2lmUZclzmLsqfDZ2czAcHQW_8PnabZvy1ZYBXw/s1439/DP-ML.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="494" data-original-width="1439" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgQqxkabmVXlVWrPH4rEop_ZFxMo_DtkzllZq3JIpstNNxAxutrZe-kS24Vqi1b2r4BvF1zEP3hpZGEvoExnJHKqgnREGcgTJWSjmfglItZAa_ZHLrsTTRvLBxY4z6nmeJoT1ptEnM9dkM82Iq8_FCA2lmUZclzmLsqfDZ2czAcHQW_8PnabZvy1ZYBXw/s16000/DP-ML.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;DP-SGD is a modification of SGD that involves a) clipping per-example gradients to limit the sensitivity and b) adding the noise, calibrated to the sensitivity and privacy guarantees, to the aggregated gradients, before the gradient update step. </td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Existing DP-training challenges</h2>; <p>; Gradient noise injection methods usually exhibit: (1) loss of utility, (2) slower training, and (3) an increased <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_footprint">;memory footprint</a>;. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Loss of utility</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;The best method for reducing utility drop is to use more computation. Using larger batch sizes and/or more iterations is one of the most prominent and practical ways of improving a model's performance. Hyperparameter tuning is also extremely important but often overlooked. The utility of DP-trained models is sensitive to the total amount of noise added, which depends on hyperparameters, like the clipping norm and batch size. Additionally, other hyperparameters like the learning rate should be re-tuned to account for noisy gradient updates. </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Another option is to obtain more data or use public data of similar distribution. This can be done by leveraging publicly available checkpoints, like <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1512.03385">;ResNet</a>; or <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/1910.10683.pdf">;T5</a>;, and fine-tuning them using private data. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Slower training</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Most gradient noise injection methods limit sensitivity via clipping per-example gradients, considerably slowing down <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation">;backpropagation</a>;. This can be addressed by choosing an efficient DP framework that efficiently implements per-example clipping. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Increased memory footprint</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;DP-training requires significant memory for computing and storing per-example gradients. Additionally, it requires significantly larger batches to obtain better utility. Increasing the computation resources (eg, the number and size of accelerators) is the simplest solution for extra memory requirements. Alternatively, <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2109.12298">;several</a>; <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.12328">;works</a>; advocate for gradient accumulation where smaller batches are combined to simulate a larger batch before the gradient update is applied. Further, some algorithms (eg, <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/2110.05679.pdf">;ghost clipping</a>;, which is based on <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1510.01799">;this paper</a>;) avoid per-example gradient clipping altogether. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Best practices</h2>; <p>; The following best practices can attain rigorous DP guarantees with the best model utility possible. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Choosing the right privacy unit:</strong>; </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;First, we should be clear about a model's privacy guarantees. This is encoded by selecting the “privacy unit,” which represents the neighboring dataset concept (ie, datasets where only one row is different). Example-level protection is a common choice in the research literature, but may not be ideal, however, for user-generated data if individual users contributed multiple records to the training dataset. For such a case, user-level protection might be more appropriate. For text and sequence data, the choice of the unit is harder since in most applications individual training examples are not aligned to the semantic meaning embedded in the text. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Choosing privacy guarantees:</strong>; </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;We outline three broad tiers of privacy guarantees and encourage practitioners to choose the lowest possible tier below: </p>; <ul style="margin-left: 4em;">; <li>;<em>;Tier 1 — Strong privacy guarantees:</em>; Choosing <em>;ε</em>; ≤ 1 provides a strong privacy guarantee, but frequently results in a significant utility drop for large models and thus may only be feasible for smaller models. </li>;<li>;<em>;Tier 2 — Reasonable privacy guarantees:</em>; We advocate for the currently undocumented, but still widely used, goal for DP-ML models to achieve an <em>;ε</em>; ≤ 10. </li>;<li>;<em>;Tier 3 — Weak privacy guarantees:</em>; Any finite <em>;ε</em>; is an improvement over a model with no formal privacy guarantee. However, for <em>;ε</em>; > 10, the DP guarantee alone cannot be taken as sufficient evidence of data anonymization, and additional measures (eg, empirical privacy auditing) may be necessary to ensure the model protects user data. </li>; </ul>; <p>; <strong>;Hyperparameter tuning</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Choosing hyperparameters requires optimizing over three inter-dependent objectives: 1) model utility, 2) privacy cost <em>;ε</em>;, and 3) computation cost. Common strategies take two of the three as constraints, and focus on optimizing the third. We provide methods that will maximize the utility with a limited number of trials, eg, tuning with privacy and computation constraints. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Reporting privacy guarantees: </strong>; </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;A lot of works on DP for ML report only <em>;ε</em>; and possibly <em>;δ </em>;values for their training procedure. However, we believe that practitioners should provide a comprehensive overview of model guarantees that includes: </p>; <ol style="margin-left: 4em;">; <li>;<em>;DP setting:</em>; Are the results assuming central DP with a trusted service provider, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_differential_privacy">;local DP</a>;, or some other setting? </li>;<li>;<em>;Instantiating the DP definition:</em>; <ol type="a">; <li>;<em>;Data accesses covered:</em>; Whether the DP guarantee applies (only) to a single training run or also covers hyperparameter tuning etc. </li>;<li>;<em>;Final mechanism's output</em>;: What is covered by the privacy guarantees and can be released publicly (eg, model checkpoints, the full sequence of privatized gradients, etc.) </li>;<li>;<em>;Unit of privacy</em>;: The selected “privacy unit” (example-level, user-level, etc.) </li>;<li>;<em>;Adjacency definition</em>; for DP “neighboring” datasets: A description of how neighboring datasets differ (eg, add-or-remove, replace-one, zero-out-one). </li>; </ol>; </li>;<li>;<em>;Privacy accounting details:</em>; Providing accounting details, eg, composition and amplification, are important for proper comparison between methods and should include: <ol type="a">; <li>;Type of accounting used, eg, <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1702.07476">;Rényi DP</a>;-based accounting, PLD accounting, etc. </li>;<li>;Accounting assumptions and whether they hold (eg, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poisson_regression#Maximum_likelihood-based_parameter_estimation">;Poisson</a>; sampling was assumed for privacy amplification but data shuffling was used in training). </li>;<li>;Formal DP statement for the model and tuning process (eg, the specific <em>;ε</em>;, <em>;δ</em>;-DP or <em>;<a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/1605.02065.pdf">;ρ-zCDP</a>;</em>; values). </li>; </ol>; </li>;<li>;<em>;Transparency and verifiability:</em>; When possible, complete open-source code using standard DP libraries for the key mechanism implementation and accounting components. </li>; </ol>; <p>; <strong>;Paying attention to all the components used:</strong>; </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Usually, DP-training is a straightforward application of DP-SGD or other algorithms. However, some components or losses that are often used in ML models (eg, <a href="https://www.baeldung.com/cs/contrastive-learning#:~:text=Contrastive%20Loss,and%20dissimilar%20samples%20far%20apart.">;contrastive losses</a>;, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network">;graph neural network</a>; layers) should be examined to ensure privacy guarantees are not violated. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Open questions</h2>; <p>; While DP-ML is an active research area, we highlight the broad areas where there is room for improvement. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Developing better accounting methods</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Our current understanding of DP-training <em>;ε</em>;, <em>;δ<strong>; </strong>;</em>;guarantees<strong>; </strong>;relies on a number of techniques, like Rényi DP composition and privacy amplification. We believe that better accounting methods for existing algorithms will demonstrate that DP guarantees for ML models are actually better than expected. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Developing better algorithms:</strong>; </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;The computational burden of using gradient noise injection for DP-training comes from the need to use larger batches and limit per-example sensitivity. Developing methods that can use smaller batches or identifying other ways (apart from per-example clipping) to limit the sensitivity would be a breakthrough for DP-ML. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Better optimization techniques</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Directly applying the same DP-SGD recipe is believed to be suboptimal for adaptive optimizers because the noise added to privatize the gradient may accumulate in learning rate computation. Designing theoretically grounded DP adaptive optimizers remains an active research topic. Another potential direction is to better understand the surface of DP loss, since for standard (non-DP) ML models flatter regions have been shown to <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.01412">;generalize</a>; <a href="https://openreview.net/pdf?id=H1oyRlYgg">;better</a>;. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Identifying architectures that are more robust to noise</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;There's an opportunity to better understand whether we need to adjust the architecture of an existing model when introducing DP. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Conclusion</h2>; <p>; Our <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00654">;survey paper</a>; summarizes the current research related to making ML models DP, and provides practical tips on how to achieve the best privacy-utility trade offs. Our hope is that this work will serve as a reference point for the practitioners who want to effectively apply DP to complex ML models. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>; <em>;We thank Hussein Hazimeh, Zheng Xu , Carson Denison , H. Brendan McMahan, Sergei Vassilvitskii, Steve Chien and Abhradeep Thakurta, Badih Ghazi, Chiyuan Zhang for the help preparing this blog post, paper and tutorials content. Thanks to John Guilyard for creating the graphics in this post, and Ravi Kumar for comments.</em>; </p>;</content>;<link href="http://ai.googleblog.com/feeds/3261601760457492933/comments/default"
